evidence: As part of her duties as California’s attorney general, Kamala Harris wrote the title and summary language for Proposition 57, a 2016 state ballot measure. | Harris neither wrote the proposed law nor openly supported it — and her work did not result in any crimes being "redefined" as nonviolent. | Proposition 57, which passed, allowed felons convicted of nonviolent crimes to be eligible for parole earlier. Its distinction between violent and nonviolent crimes relied on the state penal code’s pre-existing list of 23 crimes categorized as "violent."
label: refutes

claim: In Glynn County, Georgia, it was 'voter fraud' when poll workers found no record of a person who already voted.
evidence: A system lag in Glynn County, Georgia, meant that a person who had already cast a ballot at a different early voting site hadn’t been marked off yet, an election official told PolitiFact. The voter had not tried to vote more than once, but was at a voting site to assist a disabled person who was voting. | If the person had voted twice, the system would have detected it once the system update was complete.
label: refutes

claim: Data shows some voters cast multiple votes, meaning "at least 164,568 illegal votes have been cast” in Michigan.
evidence: Michigan’s Qualified Voter File keeps registered voters’ previous addresses attached to their voter IDs, but only the most recent registered address is active. | Michigan’s secretary of state said a formatting error in an early voting report from the file generated a line for each voter’s associated address, showing multiple addresses associated with the same voter ID for some. | There were not multiple ballots cast and counted from the same voter ID. Only one vote can be counted with each ID, officials said. The error has been fixed.
label: refutes

claim: U.S. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene said on X, “New York and California are absolutely flipping red.”
evidence: U.S. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., didn’t say this. It appeared on a parody X account.
label: refutes

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris didn’t respond to questions about a cognitive test in a CBS News interview that aired Oct. 28, 2024.
evidence: Vice President Kamala Harris said in a CBS News interview that aired Oct. 28 she would take a cognitive test and challenged former President Donald Trump to do the same.
label: refutes

claim: An E. coli outbreak followed former President Donald Trump’s campaign stop at a Pennsylvania McDonald’s.
evidence: People started getting sick Sept. 27 from an E. coli outbreak connected to onions served at McDonald’s, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said. | No one has been sickened by the outbreak since Oct. 16, which was four days before former President Donald Trump’s Oct. 20 campaign visit to a Pennsylvania McDonald’s. | No known cases of E. coli were reported in Pennsylvania.
label: refutes

claim: Photos show Vice President Kamala Harris when she was “a former call girl in California.”
evidence: This claim is unfounded.
label: refutes

claim: Sen. Jon Tester “voted to let men compete against our girls in their sports.”
evidence: Sen. Jon Tester, D-Mont., voted against two amendments to broader spending bills that would have stripped funding from schools that allowed transgender athletes to compete in sports matching their gender identity. | Those amendments did not determine athletic eligibility. | Montana is one of 26 states that bars transgender athletes from competing in sports matching their gender identity.
label: refutes

claim: El expresidente Donald Trump “se vistio de negro y dorado, colores del grupo Proud Boys” en mitín en el Madison Square Garden el 27 de octubre del 2024.
evidence: El expresidente Donald Trump vistió un traje azul y una corbata roja el 27 de octubre en su evento de campaña en el Madison Square Garden en Nueva York. | Él visitió un traje negro y una corbata dorada-amarilla el 25 de octubre en un mitin en Traverse City, Michigan.
label: refutes

claim: "Right to Try" experimental drug program saved "thousands and thousands of lives."
evidence: Despite President Donald Trump’s claim, there’s no evidence the program had anywhere close to the effect he said it had — and experts say the measure weakened existing patient protections. | Although Trump has promised to expand the program if he wins the election, it’s unclear what more he could do.
label: refutes

claim: “I’ve not gotten a single call from the White House.”
evidence: White House records show a staff member emailed and called North Carolina Rep. Tim Moore’s office offering assistance. | Moore wasn’t aware of that outreach when he made his claim on Oct. 21, he told PolitiFact.
label: uncertain

claim: “Revolucionarios Comunistas de América” marcharon a favor de Kamala Harris.
evidence: La imagen en la publicación en Instagram se publicó en una cuenta de parodia en X el 28 de julio. | Los Comunistas Revolucionarios de América marcharon en Filadelfia el 28 de julio para celebrar el aniversario de la fundación de su partido. | Esta marcha sucedió un mes antes de que la vicepresidente Kamala Harris fuera por primera vez a Filadelfia como candidata presidencial demócrata. PolitiFact no encontró reportes de medios verídicos sobre manifestaciones comunistas a favor de Harris.
label: refutes

claim: Says opponent Eric Hovde “opposes efforts to negotiate with the big pharmaceutical companies to lower the price of prescription drugs.”
evidence: Repblican U.S. Senate candidate Eric Hovde opposes the Inflation Reduction Act, which among other things, makes it possible to negotiate drug prices. | But he says drug prices are too high and negotiations with Big Pharma are needed
label: uncertain

claim: Video shows Kamala Harris saying, “Trump is literally Hitler,” on Joe Rogan’s podcast.
evidence: This video is fabricated. | Vice President Kamala Harris has not appeared on "The Joe Rogan Experience" podcast. | Harris has not called former President Donald Trump "Adolf Hitler." She has spoken about statements from his former chief of staff, who said in recorded interviews with The New York Times that Trump more than once spoke positively about Hitler, the German Nazi dictator.
label: refutes

claim: "El fondo de innovación para la deuda americana está ayudando a los hispanoamericanos a borrar hasta $50,000 de deuda de tarjetas de crédito...para evitar otra recesión".
evidence: Un portavoz de la oficina de rentas internas le dijo a PolitiFact que el "fondo de innovación para la deuda americana" no existe. | Tampoco encontramos reportes verídicos de un fondo que elimine deudas de tarjetas de crédito a los hispanos. | El video usa falsamente la imagen de la que fue presentadora del Noticiero Univision, María Elena Salinas y del presentador de Noticias Telemundo, Octavio Pulido.
label: refutes

claim: In Lancaster, Pa., “We caught them with 2,600 votes. We caught them cold, 2,600 votes. ... And every vote was written by the same person."
evidence: Lancaster County, Pennsylvania, officials said Oct. 25 that they were investigating 2,500 voter registration applications. An early statement from the county said they were investigating "ballots," but an official said that was a typo. | Staff noticed that numerous applications appeared to have the same handwriting and were filled out on the same day. Some applications were for previously registered voters and their signatures did not match the ones on file.
label: refutes

claim: Kamala Harris paid The Shade Room to interview her “for perceived support amongst black voters.”
evidence: The Shade Room’s founder, Angie Nwandu, told PolitiFact that Harris’ campaign did not pay for the interview. | We searched Google and the Nexis news database for reports on a leak revealing that Harris paid to be on The Shade Room but found no credible results.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows “illegal ‘voters’ cutting the line” to vote in Pennsylvania.
evidence: Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, election officials said in a statement that a viral video captured a brief conversation between a group of voters, their translators and a local election official at a polling location. | The voters in the video were there to apply for mail-in ballots. The older and disabled voters were allowed to sit, rather than stand in line, as their applications were processed, which is standard procedure, the county said. | Only U.S. citizens who are registered to vote in Pennsylvania would have been able to apply for a mail-in ballot, the county said.
label: refutes

claim: "AOC is worth 29 Million dollars! How did that happen, on $174,000 per year?"
evidence: There’s no evidence that Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y., is worth $29 million. | Her yearly congressional salary is $174,000. A financial disclosure report for 2023 lists four assets worth $3,004 to $46,000 and student loan liabilities from $15,001 to $50,000.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows people “marching in Puerto Rico” after former President Donald Trump’s Madison Square Garden rally.
evidence: This video predates former President Donald Trump’s Madison Square Garden rally and was filmed in Brazil before the country’s local elections that started Oct. 6.
label: refutes

claim: In Fordyce, Arkansas, voting machines changed votes from Republican to Democrat.
evidence: Voting machines in Fordyce, Arkansas, are not flipping votes from Republican to Democrat. | Election workers examined the voting machine in Fordyce after a complaint was made and found no problems with it. | Chris Madison, director of the Arkansas State Board of Election Commissioners, told PolitiFact such complaints often result from voter mistakes. In such instances, poll workers are notified, the ballots are spoiled and the voters are allowed to vote again.
label: refutes

claim: Says Eric Hovde “claims anyone who believes in transitioning to a clean energy economy is ‘smoking crack cocaine.’”
evidence: During a Nov. 17, 2022, appearance at Sunwest Bank’s Economic Forum, Hovde said that if people think an economy can transition from its existing fuel sources "in a matter of a decade," they are smoking crack cocaine. | In this remark and other similar ones, Hovde is casting doubt on the pace of the clean energy transition, not saying anyone who thinks it can happen at all is kidding themselves. That’s a key distinction. | Hovde has derided clean energy initiatives in the past, and energy experts critiqued the usefulness of his overall point here. But that doesn’t change that he didn’t say what the group claims he did.
label: refutes

claim: “Feds RAID Jay Z & Beyonce Mansion After Diddy LINKS,” arrest couple.
evidence: Beyoncé and Jay-Z have not been arrested, nor was their home raided by federal authorities in the Sean "Diddy" Combs sex trafficking case. | We traced a Threads post making that claim to a YouTube page that has a disclaimer saying its videos "sometimes contain information not to be considered as the truth."
label: refutes

claim: A Montana Democratic operative was caught tampering with a ballot box.
evidence: The Glacier County sheriff's office investigated an incident in which a Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee employee was videotaped appearing to tug at a ballot box. It found the incident "does not constitute a legitimate attempt to tamper with the ballot box."
label: refutes

claim: A Pennsylvania TV station aired the 2024 presidential election results early.
evidence: WNEP-TV, an ABC News affiliate in Moosic, Pennsylvania, accidentally aired test 2024 presidential election results in October. But the results aren’t real, nor are they evidence of election interference. This also happened with other TV stations during the 2020 election. | The station said the numbers on the screen were randomly generated test results that help news organizations make sure their equipment is working properly in advance of election night.
label: supports

claim: Former President Donald Trump wore “Proud Boy gang colors” Oct. 27, 2024, at Madison Square Garden.
evidence: Former President Donald Trump wore a blue suit and red tie Oct. 27 at his Madison Square Garden rally. He wore a black suit and golden-yellow tie at an Oct. 25 rally in Traverse City, Michigan.
label: refutes

claim: Image shows an anti-Trump billboard outside Madison Square Garden.
evidence: The image is altered. | The original photo taken April 20, 2020, showed a sign that said "We (Love) New York," with a heart shape representing the word "love." | The sign’s sentiment was shared as a pandemic quickly spread through New York City, one of the COVID-19 outbreak’s early U.S. hotspots.
label: refutes

claim: "The cocaine found in the White House was Kamala’s.”
evidence: This claim is unfounded. The U.S. Secret Service closed its investigation without a suspect citing a lack of evidence.
label: refutes

claim: “Kamala campaign photoshops her with a McDonald’s uniform!”
evidence: There’s no evidence that Vice President Kamala Harris’ presidential campaign edited a photo to show her wearing a McDonald’s uniform. An X user took credit for the image and said it was fake.
label: refutes

claim: At Vice President Kamala Harris’ Houston campaign rally, when an attendee had a medical emergency, none of the “abortion doctors” onstage helped.
evidence: At Vice President Kamala Harris’ Oct. 25 Houston rally, a few minutes into Dr. Todd Ivey’s speech about the importance of abortion access, people from the crowd called out. Initially, the words were inaudible and interspersed with people booing the abortion access limitations Ivey described. | Once it was clear someone had summoned a medic, Ivey amplified the call for help and gestured to where help was needed. He kept gesturing until it was confirmed aid was provided.
label: refutes

claim: Photos show federal authorities arrested and charged a clone instead of the real Sean “Diddy” Combs.
evidence: The images are AI-generated deepfakes that spread online in March 2024. | The real Sean "Diddy" Combs remains in federal custody awaiting trial.
label: refutes

claim: "Nicki Minaj just endorsed Donald Trump for President.”
evidence: There’s no evidence that rapper Nicki Minaj has publicly endorsed Donald Trump over Kamala Harris for president. | Some posts making the claim shared a 5-year-old video in which she didn’t endorse Trump.
label: refutes

claim: “Jacky Rosen voted to allow biological men to compete in women’s sports.”
evidence: Sen. Jacky Rosen, D-Nev., voted against two failed amendments to broader federal funding bills. The amendments would have stripped federal funding from schools and colleges that allowed transgender girls and women to compete in sports matching their gender identity. The legislation did not dictate athletic eligibility. | Federal law rarely dictates who is eligible for specific sports. | Republicans have made similar claims against Democrats in other competitive races.
label: refutes

claim: “In Montana, we cherish our public lands. But Tim Sheehy called to transfer them off, so the ultra-rich can buy them up.”
evidence: Republican U.S. Senate candidate Tim Sheehy has said local interests should get a greater voice in managing federal land. However, he’s consistently said he opposes federal transfers or sales of federal lands, and he has not urged sales to the "ultra-rich." | Unlike Sheehy, the state Republican Party platform explicitly calls for land transfers, and the federal government has negotiated land swaps with private landholders in recent years, at a time of growing interest by well-heeled outsiders in buying up Montana land.
label: refutes

claim: El expresidente Donald Trump dijo “ESTOY PIDIENDO LA PENA DE (MUERTE) PARA CUALQUIER MIGRANTE”.
evidence: El expresidente Donald Trump y candidato presidencial republicano apoya la pena de muerte para cualquier inmigrante que asesine a un ciudadano estadounidense o agente de la ley. | Pero la publicación en Facebook omite ese contexto importante.
label: refutes

claim: There are “180,000 registered new Amish voters in Lancaster, Pennsylvania.”
evidence: About 93,000 Amish people live in Pennsylvania and that figure includes children who are not eligible to register to vote. | In Lancaster County, there are about 38,000 Amish people. | Pennsylvania’s voter registration form does not ask about religious identity. The Pennsylvania Department of State told NewsGuard, a company tracking online misinformation, that claims about 180,000 Amish voters in Pennsylvania were inaccurate.
label: refutes

claim: “Milwaukee is one of the sex trafficking capitals in our country.”
evidence: Multiple state departments and law enforcement confirm human and sex trafficking does take place in Milwaukee. | The crime itself, compared with other crimes in the city, is low. | Law enforcement and victim advocates find challenges tracking this data, making it difficult to say with certainty that it’s a worse problem in one place compared with another.
label: supports

claim: “Elon Musk launches new pregnancy robot.”
evidence: Tesla CEO Elon Musk recently talked about the potential of the company’s Optimus robots, but we found no evidence to support the claim that he’s working on a surrogate android.
label: refutes

claim: Vice Presidential nominee Tim Walz “says that if Democrats win they’ll make (U.S. Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez) speaker of the house.”
evidence: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, the Democratic vice presidential nominee, did not say Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, D-N.Y, would be the next House speaker if Democrats win back the House in November. | Walz said Democrats will win the election and told Ocasio-Cortez they would "put a gavel in your hand in the House." In the House, the head of every committee or subcommittee controls the gavel in their hearings; there are 20 standing House committees and 104 subcommittees.
label: refutes

claim: "Circula este video de un hombre que rompe los votos para Donald Trump y guarda las de Kamala Harris”.
evidence: Este video no muestra a un trabajador electoral destruyendo boletas en el condado Bucks, Pensilvania. Los materiales que se están rompiendo no son auténticos. | La Junta Electoral del condado Bucks emitió una declaración bipartidista en la que afirma que "este video es falso". Autoridades federales también dijeron que es falso. | Un experto en análisis forense digital le dijo a PolitiFact que la narrativa del video es obra de una red rusa llamada Storm-1516.
label: refutes

claim: An old photo shows Kamala Harris in a McDonald’s uniform.
evidence: The edited image substituted Vice President Kamala Harris’ face for that of a woman in a McDonald’s uniform named Suzanne Bernier, who died in 2007. | An X user took credit for creating the image and said it is fake.
label: refutes

claim: “Beyonce got paid $10 MILLION for her speech” at a Kamala Harris rally.
evidence: PolitiFact searched Google and the Nexis news database and found no credible reports that the Harris-Walz campaign paid Beyoncé to endorse Vice President Kamala Harris or give remarks at a Houston rally on Oct. 25. | Beyoncé’s publicist told PolitiFact that the claim was "beyond ridiculous."
label: refutes

claim: Four Florida counties had “zero results” Oct. 26, and “something underhanded might be happening.”
evidence: A screenshot showed zero ballots cast during early voting in four Florida counties as of the morning of Oct. 26. | That’s not suspicious. Those four counties began early voting within two hours of the screenshot's timestamp.
label: refutes

claim: Photo shows people lined up outside Madison Square Garden before an Oct. 27 rally by former President Donald Trump.
evidence: This image was taken in 2011 and showed people waiting to get into a Dublin event featuring then-President Barack Obama.
label: refutes

claim: Sen. Bob Casey "has voted in lockstep with his liberal party to defund the police."
evidence: U.S. Sen. Bob Casey, D-Pa., backed a bill aimed at addressing police misconduct and racial bias in 2020. The bill would have required police departments to enact reforms to qualify for federal funds. | The bill would not have cut any police department budgets and would not have reduced the federal money being spent on local police. In some cases, it would have created new grants for local departments.
label: refutes

claim: “BREAKING: Lizzo charged the Harris-Walz campaign $2.3 million for a single appearance at a Detroit rally.”
evidence: We searched Google and the Nexis news database and we found no credible news reports or other evidence that the Harris-Walz campaign paid Lizzo for her appearance at an Oct. 19 campaign event. | This claim circulated widely on X, with some posts receiving millions of views, but none of the posts offered proof.
label: refutes

claim: “Ballots are not supposed to have fold lines or creases in the candidates name area” or it could invalidate your vote.
evidence: Mark Lindeman, the policy and strategy director for Verified Voting, said a crease through a candidate’s name would have no impact on tabulating machines’ ability to read a ballot. | If a crease goes through the spot where voters mark their choice, multiple backup procedures ensure the vote is counted. | New Hampshire conducted a recount on some 2020 ballots that were creased where the vote is recorded. But the state passed bipartisan legislation to change the scanner settings so the problem wouldn’t happen again.
label: refutes

claim: Scott Lassiter “repeatedly campaigned to promote” North Carolina's “largest-ever” school funding cut, sending public school money to “unaccountable private schools” and ending science education.
evidence: Republican Scott Lassiter has said he’s OK with using taxpayer dollars on private schools, so long as there’s accountability for the schools receiving the funds. | Democratic state Sen. Lisa Grafstein said Lassiter signaled his support for the other positions by appearing with Lt. Gov. Mark Robinson and Michele Morrow, the Republican nominee for education superintendent. | Lassiter says he hasn't endorsed either candidate, and has publicly called for Robinson to suspend his campaign for governor.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows an election worker destroying mail ballots with votes for former President Donald Trump in Bucks County, Pennsylvania.
evidence: This video does not show an election worker destroying ballots in Bucks County, Pennsylvania. The materials being ripped are not authentic. | The Bucks County Board of Elections issued a bipartisan statement saying "this video is fake." | A media forensics expert told PolitiFact that the video's narrative is the work of a Russian network called Storm-1516.
label: refutes

claim: Kamala Harris’ statements about Trump invoking Adolf Hitler were based on a “debunked hoax from The Atlantic.”
evidence: John Kelly, a retired U.S. Marine Corps general and former President Donald Trump’s longest-serving chief of staff, told The Atlantic and The New York Times that Trump spoke positively about Adolf Hitler. | Social media posts misleadingly conflated those legitimate news articles with a falsified image that was created as a satirical take on The Atlantic’s report and bore the fabricated headline, "Trump is Literally Hitler."
label: refutes

claim: Kamala Harris "proclaimed she would not accept the outcome of the election and has a team of lawyers ready to overturn them"
evidence: We reviewed the transcript of the NBC News interview and found that Vice President Kamala Harris didn’t say she wouldn’t accept the 2024 election results. | In the interview, she criticized former President Donald Trump for trying to overturn the 2020 election results. | Harris said her campaign had a team ready in case Trump declared victory on election night while votes are still being counted. But that’s not evidence of a plot to overturn the election result.
label: refutes

claim: Kamala Harris imprisoned a woman for three years for praying.
evidence: Bevelyn Beatty Williams was sentenced to 41 months in prison for violating the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act, or the FACE Act, for physically obstructing access to a Manhattan Planned Parenthood and threatening patients and workers in June 2020. | Williams was convicted in February after a unanimous jury found her guilty; Manhattan Judge Jennifer L. Rochon sentenced her. | Vice President Kamala Harris was not involved in the case or the decision.
label: refutes

claim: “El gobernador de la Florida dice que por el momento va a pausar” la ley S.B. 1718 porque necesitan que los hispanos reconstruyan el estado tras la destrucción del huracán Milton.
evidence: Una portavoz del gobernador de Florida, Ron DeSantis, le dijo a PolitiFact que la ley S.B. 1718 sigue vigente.
label: refutes

claim: "The Defense Department, with the stroke of a pen, has quietly codified its right to deploy lethal force against its own citizens.”
evidence: The U.S. Defense Department on Sept. 27 released a revised directive, 5240.01, which provides policy guidance for situations in which the department’s intelligence agencies — such as the National Security Agency — are assisting civilian authorities. Updates to directives are common. | The updated directive 5240.01 does not grant any new power to the Defense Department and does not grant legal authority for the military to use lethal force on civilians, the department and experts said. | The Posse Comitatus Act generally prevents federal armed forces from participating in civilian law enforcement, with exceptions for the Insurrection Act, last used during the 1992 Los Angeles uprising. The Posse Comitatus Act does not apply to National Guard troops, which report to state leaders.
label: refutes

claim: El expresidente Donald Trump quiere eliminar la Ley del Cuidado de Salud a Bajo Precio.
evidence: El anuncio de la campaña de Harris utiliza un video de 2017 en el que el expresidente Donald Trump dijo que su administración planeaba "derogar y reemplazar el Obamacare". | Trump ha dicho en repetidas ocasiones que quiere reemplazar la Ley del Cuidado de Salud a Bajo Precio (ACA, por sus siglas en inglés). Pero últimamente ha dicho que quiere mejorarla y presentar su propio plan, aunque no ha ofrecido detalles.
label: supports

claim: “Land O Lakes has announced the return of the iconic squaw to its packaging.”
evidence: This claim originated on a self-described satire site. We found no evidence the dairy company is bringing back its old logo.
label: refutes

claim: "Ruben Gallego wanted to defund the police. He actually co-sponsored legislation to defund the police.”
evidence: Rep. Ruben Gallego, D-Ariz., co-sponsored a bill introduced in 2019 that would have restricted the transfer of military-grade weapons to police departments. | However, this is not only a different issue but it occurred the year before "defund the police" became a rallying cry for some progressives. | Gallego has backed several bills since 2019 that provide added funding for recruitment and retention of police officers.
label: refutes

claim: “The cheat has begun” because “Michigan, Georgia and Pennsylvania have officially announced that they will not have election results available on election night.”
evidence: Counting ballots takes time, and it’s not evidence of election fraud if a state doesn’t report a winner on election night.
label: refutes

claim: The Biden-Harris administration “brought over” 10 million migrants who got 9 million jobs.
evidence: U.S. Customs and Border Protection has recorded 10.5 million encounters so far during President Joe Biden’s presidency. More than 4.2 million of the 10.5 million encounters resulted in people being deported from the country. | U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics data shows employment for foreign-born people in the U.S. is up by 6.1 million since Biden took office. But this figure refers to all people born outside of the U.S., not just migrants who came to the U.S. during Biden’s presidency.
label: refutes

claim: Ballot drop boxes 'were only used for a pandemic.'
evidence: Drop boxes had been used for years without incident. | The popularity of drop boxes exploded during the 2020 pandemic. | The Wisconsin Supreme Court ruled drop boxes were illegal in 2022; the court restored use of the boxes in 2024.
label: refutes

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris has been “going so far as to call me Adolf Hitler.”
evidence: Vice President Kamala Harris did not call former President Donald Trump "Adolf Hitler." In Oct. 23 comments, Harris referred to recent New York Times reporting in which former Trump Chief of Staff John Kelly said Trump had said admiring things about Hitler and Hitler’s military control. | Kelly said Trump "commented more than once that, ‘You know, Hitler did some good things, too.’" Kelly also confirmed other reports about Trump speaking admiringly of Hitler’s military control and asking why Trump’s generals couldn’t be more like Hilter’s. Trump denied making the comments. | Harris called Trump a fascist, pointing to Trump’s public statements about an "enemy from within" that would cause Election Day chaos, floating the idea that the National Guard or military might be used against them.
label: refutes

claim: Voting machines in Shelby County, Tennessee, are swapping votes from Kamala Harris to Donald Trump.
evidence: Some early voters in Shelby County, Tennessee, told Democratic state legislators that voting machine touchscreens were registering candidates they didn’t select. | Election officials said there were no machine malfunctions. Voters using their fingers to click a small box inside a larger box on the ballots might have inadvertently selected the candidate listed above. | Officials urged voters to click the candidates’ names in the center of the box or use a provided stylus to mark the ballots.
label: refutes

claim: “Schaumburg, Illinois not recording votes, just putting votes ‘in a box.’”
evidence: The ballot scanner in an early voting location in Schaumburg, Illinois, was temporarily down Oct. 21. It was restored by 2 p.m. the same day. | In the event of a ballot scanner issue, ballots are placed in an "alternate ballot box" and are processed after the ballot scanner is restored. Election judges feed the ballots in the scanner; at least one person from each party is present. | A spokesperson for the Cook County Clerk’s Office said all 760 voters who cast a ballot in the Schaumburg early voting location had their votes counted the same day.
label: refutes

claim: "As of today, we have cut the flow of immigration by over half."
evidence: The size of the drop varies based on what time frame is used, but over roughly the past year, the number of encounters along the southwestern U.S. border — a common way to measure immigration — has declined by 57% to 78%.
label: supports

claim: "Breaking: Voters in Tarrant County, Texas are reporting that the voting machines are flipping their votes from Trump to Kamala Harris."
evidence: Only one person out of more than 100,000 voters in Tarrant County has reported having a vote for former President Donald Trump changed to Vice President Kamala Harris when the ballot was printed. | Local election officials said the voting machines are not flipping candidates and suggested the voter made a mistake when selecting preferred candidates. | That ballot was destroyed and the voter was allowed to vote again.
label: refutes

claim: “Elon Musk reportedly eyeing CNN acquisition: ‘I’ll fix the media, one network at a time.’”
evidence: This claim isn’t true. It originated on a self-described satire site.
label: refutes

claim: “Elon Musk urges a boycott of ABC Network: ‘Let’s take them down!’”
evidence: This claim originated on a self-described satire site. X owner Elon Musk didn’t urge people to boycott ABC.
label: refutes

claim: Lt. Gen. H.R. McMaster was arrested “for aiding FEMA in deep state’s ‘eminent domain’ takeover of North Carolina.”
evidence: This claim is "absolutely false," a spokesperson for the Federal Emergency Management Agency said.
label: refutes

claim: Michigan U.S. Senate candidate Mike Rogers “wants to cut Medicare and Social Security.”
evidence: During a previous stint in Congress, Michigan Republican U.S. Senate candidate Mike Rogers supported plans to overhaul Medicare and raise the eligibility age for benefits. Whether those plans would have led to higher costs for beneficiaries would have depended on several factors, but the plans never became law. | Rogers has said during this campaign that he does not support cuts to the programs. He’s called for a bipartisan commission to address the programs’ funding shortfalls.
label: refutes

claim: Former President Donald Trump wants to take away the Affordable Care Act.
evidence: The Harris’ campaign ad uses a 2017 video in which former President Donald Trump said his administration planned on "repealing and replacing Obamacare." | Trump has repeatedly said he wants to replace the Affordable Care Act. But lately, he’s said he wants to fix it and introduce his own plan, though he’s offered no specifics.
label: supports

claim: "Se ha desaparecido el famoso Dr. Juan Rivera después de revelar este simple secreto de salud que podría dejar los hospitales vacíos", la ashwagandha.
evidence: La gerente de la práctica del Dr. Juan Rivera le dijo a PolitiFact que el doctor no ha desaparecido. | PolitiFact no encontró reportes verídicos en medios de comunicación sobre su desaparición. | El producto promocionado en la publicación no es de Santo Remedio, la marca oficial del doctor.
label: refutes

claim: Says opponent Eric Hovde “supports a $4 trillion tax plan that would disproportionately advantage the well-off and profitable corporations”
evidence: Republican Eric Hovde, a U.S. Senate candidate in Wisconsin, has publicly supported former President Donald Trump’s 2017 tax cut program. | That same program is projected to benefit the wealthy far more than the middle class, while raising the U.S. debt, an analysis shows.
label: supports

claim: A photo shows The Atlantic published a story headlined “Trump is Literally Hitler.”
evidence: The Atlantic did not publish an article that said "Trump is Literally Hitler." The X user who shared it later said the image was "satire." | The image is a manipulation of a screenshot of a real Atlantic article titled "Trump: ‘I need the kind of generals that Hitler had.’" It also used art that accompanied a 2023 opinion article from The Washington Post.
label: refutes

claim: “Breaking news: Elon Musk endorses Caitlin Clark, will soon donate $10 million: ‘You are the pride of America, I support you.’”
evidence: This claim is unfounded.
label: refutes

claim: Jussie Smollett is Kamala Harris’ nephew.
evidence: Jussie Smollett’s parents are not Kamala Harris’ siblings. They are also not the siblings of Kamala Harris’ husband nor her sister’s husband. | Smollett’s mother and Harris share the same maiden name. This is not proof that they are sisters. "Harris" is the 25th most popular surname in the U.S., according to 2010 Census data. | Harris’ parents are Indian and Jamaican; Smollett’s ancestry is African American, Russian and Polish.
label: refutes

claim: "Reports from Whitfield County, GA that Dominion machines are flipping votes. This is exactly the kind of fraud we saw in 2020."
evidence: Whitfield County’s Board of Elections said there were no problems with the county’s voting machines. In the case of a voter whose choices were not accurately reflected on the printed ballot, a poll worker helped the voter and the problem was resolved on-site. | The Whitfield County Board of Elections said "no machines have been taken out of service."
label: refutes

claim: “BREAKING: Diddy hospitalized after being jumped in prison.”
evidence: This claim is unfounded.
label: refutes

claim: “Liberal woman films herself eating dog food” because she said, “I’m eating dog food until Kamala is president.”
evidence: This video was altered. The original shows a Polish TikTok creator who pretends to be a dog. She doesn’t vow to eat dog food until Vice President Kamala Harris is elected president.
label: refutes

claim: Michigan has “more registered voters than eligible citizens. This creates a huge risk of election fraud.”
evidence: Michigan’s State Department said the state has about 8.4 million registered voters, which includes inactive voters who have not yet been removed from voting rolls. State and federal laws dictate the time frame for removing inactive voters from the rolls. | The state has 7.2 million active voters, and a voting-age population of about 7.9 million.
label: refutes

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris “wants struggling seniors to pay more Social Security taxes while she gives Medicare and Social Security to illegals.”
evidence: Vice President Kamala Harris has not proposed raising Social Security taxes for older Americans. Rather, she has proposed lifting the payroll income tax cap beyond which the government stops taxing workers. | The people who would pay higher taxes under Harris’ proposal are neither older nor struggling. They’re workers who benefit from the current cap that applies only to higher-income taxpayers. | Harris said in 2019 that she would like to see immigrants in the U.S. illegally qualify for universal health coverage. She has not repeated that since becoming the vice president or the presidential nominee.
label: refutes

claim: “Breaking: Florida Governor Ron DeSantis says Dominion voting systems will NOT operate in the state of Florida. ”
evidence: We found no evidence, such as news stories or social media posts, that Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis said Dominion Voting Systems will not be used in his state. | Dominion Voting Systems is certified by Florida’s Division of Elections. | Dominion’s Democracy Suite system will be used in 18 of Florida’s 67 counties, according to a Florida state elections website.
label: refutes

claim: “We're bankrupting a lot of hospitals by forcing these hospitals to provide care for people who don't have the legal right to be in our country.”
evidence: JD Vance blamed immigration for stressing rural hospitals and causing some to close. But this overlooks the reasons reported by these hospitals and studied by researchers. | Low Medicare and Medicaid reimbursement rates, along with decreasing patient use, contribute to hospital closures. Hospitals have fixed costs, such as for running emergency departments, and must have a high enough patient volume to cover them. | Just because people are not legally in the U.S. doesn’t mean they lack access to health insurance or other means to pay for hospital care.
label: refutes

claim: “There was a bill to basically create a ban to make sure we never become a sanctuary state, that no locality passes those regulations, and (former Manchester Mayor Joyce Craig) opposed that bill.”
evidence: Former Manchester Mayor Joyce Craig opposed a 2023 bill that would have prohibited "any state or local government entity from establishing sanctuary policies," alongside Manchester’s police chief and other law enforcement officials. | Former U.S. Sen. Kelly Ayotte’s remark glossed over Craig’s support for Manchester’s 13-year-old policy, which includes cooperation with federal immigration officials when people are arrested in the city for felonies and violent misdemeanors. | Craig has also said she would not turn New Hampshire into a sanctuary state if elected.
label: supports

claim: Gubernatorial candidate Kelly Ayotte “has voted for national abortion bans, she has voted to defund Planned Parenthood, and she shepherded Neil Gorsuch through the Supreme Court process, and then celebrated when Roe v. Wade was overturned.”
evidence: It’s misleading to say that as a U.S. senator, Kelly Ayotte voted for a national abortion ban. Twice, Ayotte supported a bill to end abortions after 20 weeks, with exceptions after that for the mother’s life and physical health, rape and incest. | Ayotte voted several times in the Senate to defund Planned Parenthood, and she later served as the "sherpa" for Neil Gorsuch’s Supreme Court justice confirmation in the Senate. | Ayotte applauded the Supreme Court’s decision to hand responsibility for abortion law to the states.
label: supports

claim: If an election worker writes anything on your ballot before you put it in the voting machine, “your ballot could be disqualified.”
evidence: Election administrators from multiple states confirmed that election workers can’t invalidate your ballot by writing on it. | In some states such as North Carolina and Texas, election workers are required by law to mark ballots in order to ensure election security.
label: refutes

claim: The Oregon secretary of state “removed” former President Donald Trump and U.S. Sen. JD Vance from “the official state website.”
evidence: Former President Donald Trump and U.S. Sen. JD Vance, R-Ohio, don’t appear in Oregon’s voters’ guide because the Republican presidential and vice presidential nominees didn’t submit a statement for inclusion, according to the Oregon secretary of state’s office. They weren’t removed from the website.
label: refutes

claim: “Melania Trump declares that she wants a divorce.”
evidence: This claim is "totally false," according to the Trump campaign.
label: refutes

claim: Donald Trump offered “food for everyone” at his McDonald’s press conference and then left without paying.
evidence: A Guardian headline that says, "Trump offers ‘food for everyone’ at restaurant - then leaves without paying," is unrelated to former President Donald Trump’s McDonald’s campaign stop. It is an old article from June 2023 that says Trump yelled, "Food for everyone!" at the Cuban restaurant Versailles in Miami, and then left without buying anyone food. | Trump made a campaign stop at a McDonald’s in Feasterville, Pennsylvania, on Oct. 20. He gave out paper bags to prescreened people in the drive-through, The Washington Post reported.
label: refutes

claim: To pay for extending the Trump tax cuts, Dave McCormick has “made clear he’ll slash your Medicare and Social Security, and cut Medicaid for nursing home care.”
evidence: Republican U.S. Senate candidate Dave McCormick has not called for cutting Medicare and Social Security funding. | McCormick said in 2022 the programs need changes to maintain solvency, but he has not endorsed a specific plan to cut funding. He has not called for cutting Medicaid services, either. | McCormick has said in interviews this year he would not support changes to Social Security or Medicare, and he wants to cut federal spending across the board.
label: refutes

claim: Photo shows former President Donald Trump sitting on a black towel on “Fox & Friends” because “they don’t want him to stain the sofa.”
evidence: Images show former President Donald Trump sitting on the "Fox & Friends" set with his jacket fanned on either side of him. He’s not sitting on a black towel so he won’t "stain the sofa," as some social media posts have claimed.
label: refutes

claim: “Breaking news: Megyn Kelly calls for boycott of Taylor Swift after singer attends charity event in Gaza.”
evidence: Singer-songwriter Taylor Swift didn’t recently attend a charity event in Gaza. She went to a comedy show in December in New York City that benefited an aid group providing humanitarian relief in Gaza. Talk show host Megyn Kelly criticized her attendance and said she hoped people would boycott Swift’s shows.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows “Karl Rove rallying support for Kamala Harris yesterday in Pennsylvania.”
evidence: This video shows Republican strategist Karl Rove discussing his party and the 2024 presidential election Feb. 1 at a writers festival in California. It doesn’t show him rallying support for Vice President Kamala Harris, the Democratic presidential nominee, in October in Pennsylvania.
label: refutes

claim: A pro-Kamala Harris website shows she supports a mandatory gun buyback program.
evidence: Did you just get catfished by a political ad? If you have been scrolling on Facebook or Instagram lately, maybe.A group called "Progress 2028" has paid forFacebook and Instagram adsthat give the impression that they’re promoting Vice President Kamala Harris’ agenda on polarizing issues, including immigration, gun control and hydraulic fracturing aka fracking. But the Harris campaign isn’t behind the ads, and they distort her platform."Did you know?" onead reads, alongsidea picture of Harris smiling and holding a microphone. "A
label: refutes

claim: “GA election official Gabriel Sterling says audits will take place after election day because it’s ‘nerve-racking’ to count ballots in front of poll watchers.”
evidence: The person in the video describing Georgia’s risk-limiting audits is not Gabriel Sterling, chief operating officer for the Georgia secretary of state. He is identified in both the Instagram clip and the transcript of the video as Joseph Kirk, an elections supervisor in Bartow County, Georgia. | Counting votes is separate from a risk-limiting audit. Votes are counted to determine election outcomes; risk-limiting audits check a sample of ballots after an election to verify that the results have been correctly certified. | Risk-limiting audits have been conducted after election results were certified in every election since 2020, a Georgia secretary of state spokesperson said.
label: refutes

claim: "Michael Jackson discovered alive at age 65” and will testify against Sean “Diddy” Combs.
evidence: A Facebook claiming singer Michael Jackson is alive and planning to testify at Sean "Diddy" Combs’ sex trafficking trial originated on a satire website.
label: refutes

claim: Former President Donald Trump posted on Truth Social and addressed claims of his “incontinence,” saying, “I don’t poop myself.”
evidence: The image originated from a satirical post. Donald Trump made no such remarks.
label: refutes

claim: Says opponent Eric Hovde “just proposed cutting Social Security by 28%.”
evidence: Republican U.S. Senate candidate Eric Hovde has suggested multiple times pulling government spending back to 2019 levels, which presumably would have some effect on Social Security funding in general. | But he did not propose cutting benefits by 28%, and has said multiple times that he would not seek to cut retiree benefits. | Instead, his campaign has pushed for raising the retirement age for younger people as a change he’d make to the program.
label: uncertain

claim: Estas son imágenes del huracán Milton en Florida.
evidence: Esta compilación de videos en Facebook no son del huracán Milton. Estos se publicaron en internet antes de que el huracán llegará a Florida y algunas son de otras localidades.
label: refutes

claim: As part of his “charitable donations,” in 1990 Donald Trump “chartered a private plane to get Nelson Mandela to America when the U.S. government wouldn't help."
evidence: In June 1990, Nelson Mandela, an anti-apartheid activist who spent 27 years in prison, toured eight U.S. cities as part of a larger world tour. While in the U.S., Mandela traveled in one of Donald Trump’s planes. | Mandela paid Trump $130,000 to rent the plane; it wasn’t part of Trump’s "charitable donations," as some social media users claimed. | The U.S. government paid for Mandela’s security and used a military plane to transport a bulletproof limousine across states during his eight-city tour. ​
label: refutes

claim: There was an Oct. 17, 2024, hospital update about the health of Kate Middleton, Princess of Wales.
evidence: Kate Middleton, the Princess of Wales, said in a Sept. 9 video message that she finished chemotherapy for her cancer diagnosis and is cancer-free. | The social media posts link to a story with previous news that Middleton had a successful abdominal surgery in January. | Images in the posts are either years old or artificially generated.
label: refutes

claim: Kamala Harris “supports taxpayer-funded sex changes for prisoners and illegal aliens.”
evidence: During Vice President Kamala Harris’ 2019 Democratic primary run, she supported access to gender-affirming surgery for people in federal prisons and immigration detention. In recent comments, she has said she will "follow the law." | Federal law requires that prisons provide necessary medical care to inmates, and several courts have ruled that gender-affirming care, including surgery, is included. The Trump administration also acknowledged this legal obligation. | Access to gender-affirming surgery is limited. Reports show it has been provided to two federal inmates. PolitiFact found no record of immigration detainees receiving transgender surgery.
label: supports

claim: “About 400,000 manufacturing jobs in the state of Michigan will go away with EV mandates.”
evidence: The Republican U.S. Senate candidate in Michigan, former Rep. Mike Rogers, based his projection on a job estimate that included more than 100 job classifications, only 15 of which were related to car manufacturing. The estimate included jobs such as delivery drivers, airplane and boat manufacturing, and travel services. | Estimates of the labor required to create an electric vehicle vary, but recent studies have found they may take more, not less, labor to produce. | EV production may displace jobs in traditional auto manufacturing, but not at the scale Rogers said.
label: refutes

claim: The northern lights are proof of the sky “glowing with chemicals” sprayed in the sky.
evidence: The northern lights or aurora borealis are produced because of interactions between electrons and atoms and molecules of gases such as oxygen and nitrogen. Experts say sprayed chemicals could not produce long-lasting and widespread lights such as aurora. | Scientists have rejected the "chemtrails" conspiracy. ​
label: refutes

claim: “Trump's convictions have all been overturned and he is getting his $500,000,000.00 back!”
evidence: In May, a New York jury convicted former President Donald Trump on 34 counts of falsifying business records related to hush money payments to an adult film actor. | The judge overseeing the case delayed sentencing until November. Trump has appealed the verdict and is seeking to move it from state court to federal court. | Trump lost a civil defamation case and is appealing. Three other cases against him in Georgia, Florida and the District of Columbia continue.
label: refutes

claim: Photo shows Vice President Kamala Harris and Sean “Diddy” Combs.
evidence: This image was altered. The original shows Sean "Diddy" Combs and fashion designer Misa Hylton, not Vice President Kamala Harris.
label: refutes

claim: “Elon Musk takes over Taylor Swift’s X account, causing her to lose 7 million followers and $100 million in brand deals.”
evidence: This claim is unfounded.
label: refutes

claim: Arizona U.S. Senate candidate Kari Lake “was against” the child tax credit expansion “when the bill was on the floor.”
evidence: Although Kari Lake, a Republican U.S. Senate candidate, criticized the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021, she did not single out the child tax credit portion. | Lake has supported child tax credits and "baby bonuses" to reduce abortions and increase the U.S. birth rate.
label: uncertain

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris commented on President Joe Biden’s “mental fitness,” saying, “he’s not stable” and “we should all be concerned.”
evidence: This video has been deceptively edited to give the appearance that Vice President Kamala Harris called President Joe Biden "unstable" during an Oct. 16 Fox News interview. Harris used that word to describe former President Donald Trump.
label: refutes

claim: Detroit’s Oct.15, 2024, absentee ballot return rate proves election fraud.
evidence: Detroit reported a 41% absentee ballot return rate as of Oct. 15. That’s compared with a 26% return rate during the same period in 2020. | Experts told PolitiFact this is not a sign of election fraud. The return rate might be influenced by Michigan’s expanded access for absentee voting, greater voter awareness of and confidence in that method and voters’ enthusiasm for candidates and measures on the ballot. | Statewide, Michigan has seen a lower absentee ballot return rate so far this year compared with 2020. As of Oct. 15, 31% of Michiganders had returned their ballots, compared with 34% at the same time in 2020. That year, Michigan issued absentee ballot applications to all registered voters as part of its COVID-19 response.
label: refutes

claim: Fox News reported Donald Trump donated $1,300 for hurricane relief.
evidence: The image was not part of a Fox News report. It was not on Fox News’ website and a network spokesperson told PolitiFact in an email, "I can confirm this was not reported on FOX News." | The image was shared as parody and has telltale signs of being artificially generated.
label: refutes

claim: “Kamala Harris staged hurricane relief photo op with C-17, no supplies sent to victims.”
evidence: This claim is false. A mechanical issue was discovered on the plane after Vice President Kamala Harris was photographed near the aircraft, and the hurricane relief supplies were moved to another plane.
label: refutes

claim: Screenshots of documents show a former student of Democratic vice presidential candidate Tim Walz has lodged sexual abuse allegations against him.
evidence: An X account shared screenshots of a supposed former student’s emails. But the documents contained multiple inconsistencies, including the email layouts and date formatting, undermining their credibility. | The X account also manipulated facts about Democratic vice presidential candidate and Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz’s life and career, pulled from public records and news reports, to build this baseless narrative. | The X user offered no verifiable evidence to support this allegation.
label: refutes

claim: Elissa Slotkin “signed a secret agreement with a CCP-linked Chinese battery company.”
evidence: Elissa Slotkin signed a nondisclosure agreement with the Michigan Economic Development Corp. to discuss two projects in the state. | Gotion, a subsidiary of a Chinese electric vehicle battery manufacturer, was not a party to the deal, nor was the company mentioned in the document. | Slotkin signed an amendment to broadly cover projects deemed confidential by the development group, but that came after the Gotion project was publicly announced.
label: refutes

claim: Says former President Donald Trump did not lose the 2020 election.
evidence: Sen. JD Vance, R-Ohio, for several weeks avoided directly answering questions about whether Donald Trump lost the 2020 election, pivoting to the topic of censorship. | Joe Biden won 306 electoral votes to Trump’s 232. States certified the results, and Congress accepted the results showing that Biden won. | Republican officials in Trump’s administration and battlegrounds said the 2020 election was safe and secure.
label: refutes

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris' plan “will raise taxes for the typical American family by an estimated $3,000."
evidence: One independent analysis found that if Harris were to allow all of Trump’s 2017 tax law to expire, the average hit to taxpayers would be about $2,800. But that figure is irrelevant to Harris’ plan, because she has promised to renew most of the law, minus some provisions affecting incomes above $400,000. | Three independent analyses of Harris’ tax proposals have found that the bottom 60% of earners, including incomes up to about $107,000, would have their taxes cut, not raised. under her plan. And the tax increases for incomes from $107,000 to $195,000 would be well below $3,000.
label: refutes

claim: Says Donald Trump posted on Truth Social it “should be illegal” and is “election interference” for Barack Obama to criticize him.
evidence: This isn’t an authentic post from former President Donald Trump. It originated on a parody X account and was labeled there as "satire."
label: refutes

claim: CBS exposed “the fact” that Kamala Harris’ crowd sizes are inflated because her campaign bused hundreds of attendees to her New Hampshire rally.
evidence: A spokesperson for Yankee Line told PolitiFact the charter bus company hired to provide shuttle service to the rally "from an offsite parking lot 3 miles away" because of parking restrictions at the venue. | We geolocated Throwback Brewery, where the rally took place, and confirmed that its parking lot would not have been large enough to accommodate the thousands of people who were reported to have attended the event. | A Harris-Walz spokesperson told PolitiFact in August that their "campaign does not pay people to attend rallies."
label: uncertain

claim: The Sept. 10 presidential debate was edited to cut comments from Vice President Kamala Harris about “$6,400 relief checks.”
evidence: The Sept. 10 presidential debate aired live and wasn’t edited to cut references to $6,400 relief checks. Neither the moderators nor the candidates mentioned such aid.
label: refutes

claim: Journalist Bob Woodward posted on X that Donald Trump wears adult diapers.
evidence: The post originated as satire on Jan. 30, 2023.
label: refutes

claim: “FEMA helicopters caught disrupting North Carolina supplies by using a ‘rotor wash’.”
evidence: A North Carolina National Guard helicopter, not a Federal Emergency Management Agency helicopter, caused the damage to supplies while attempting to transport a generator to an overcrowded landing site. | FEMA officials and local leaders in North Carolina have rebutted claims that FEMA is confiscating donations or deliberately damaging supplies.
label: refutes

claim: La administración de Joe Biden tomó dinero de ayudas de FEMA para usarlo en inmigrantes.
evidence: La Agencia Federal para el Manejo de Emergencias de Estados Unidos (FEMA, por sus siglas en inglés) dice que no usó fondos para desastres en inmigrantes. | Durante la administración de Donald Trump, el Congreso otorgó fondos a FEMA para ayudar a inmigrantes bajo un programa para personas sin hogar y comida. En 2023 se creó un nuevo programa para migrantes que utiliza fondos de una agencia de inmigración y es administrado por FEMA. | El Congreso financia estos programas aparte.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows former Vice President Mike Pence endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris and Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz.
evidence: The video was edited in a misleading way. In the original video, Mike Pence said, "I could never vote for Kamala Harris as President of the United States, or Tim Walz as her running mate."
label: refutes

claim: Says former President Donald Trump posted on Truth Social that former President Barack Obama “was ashamed at how much better of a golfer that I am.”
evidence: This isn't an authentic Truth Social post from former President Donald Trump; it was fabricated.
label: refutes

claim: Says former President Donald Trump posted on Truth Social, “I hope that America obliterates Israel.”
evidence: Former President Donald Trump didn’t post that he hopes the United States obliterates Israel. He said he hopes that it obliterates Iran if the country’s "terrorist proxies" assassinate him.
label: refutes

claim: La vicepresidenta Kamala Harris “usó el teleprompter para contestar las preguntas” de Univision.
evidence: La vicepresidenta Kamala Harris habló el 10 de octubre en una audiencia pública de Noticias Univision en Las Vegas. | Publicaciones en redes sociales compartieron imágenes de un "teleprompter" con palabras en él. Pero representantes de Noticias Univision dijeron que las palabras estaban en español y destinadas al moderador Enrique Acevedo. | Después de que las palabras desaparecieran del apuntador electrónico, Harris siguió su respuesta durante tres minutos.
label: refutes

claim: "The ERA could also mandate that schools allow biological males to compete in girls' sports."
evidence: New York already has protections for athletes to compete in youth sports on teams that align with their gender identity. | A constitutional amendment would strengthen anti-discrimination protections that already exist for people who are transgender.
label: supports

claim: Video shows footage of Hurricane Milton in Florida.
evidence: The clips do not show footage of Hurricane Milton. | Reverse-image searches revealed most of the video clips were taken from April 2022 to September 2024, before Milton made landfall Oct. 9. They show natural disasters in Iowa, Kansas, Brazil and Vietnam. | One clip shows flooding caused by Hurricane Helene in September.
label: refutes

claim: “Wages adjusted for inflation were massively up under Donald Trump for Black men. … The (Black-white) wage gap in 2019 was actually shrinking under Donald Trump's administration.”
evidence: For both Black Americans overall and for Black men in particular, inflation-adjusted wages rose under President Donald Trump — but they rose about three times faster under President Joe Biden. | The white-Black wage gap, both overall and for men in particular, didn’t shrink under Trump, rather, it widened. The wage gap narrowed under Biden.
label: uncertain

claim: Video clips show Hurricane Milton hitting Florida “with wind speed 185 mph as Category 5”
evidence: Several video clips featured in the TikTok post were originally taken during past storms. | Hurricane Milton reached Category 5 strength, but when it made landfall in Florida, it was designated Category 3.
label: refutes

claim: Photos show that Disney World was “destroyed by Hurricane Milton.”
evidence: The photos originated from a satirical website. | Walt Disney World announced Oct. 10 that its theme parks would reopen and resume normal operations Oct. 11.
label: refutes

claim: "Kid Rock heads to North Carolina with Millions in supplies. Taylor Swift Nowhere to be Found.”
evidence: Social media claims that Kid Rock donated millions in supplies to North Carolina’s Hurricane Helene victims, while Taylor Swift did nothing, originated on a self-described satirical website. | Swift donated $5 million to the nonprofit Feeding America to help storm victims, the organization said. | Kid Rock donated either $20,000 or $50,000 to a hurricane GoFundMe started by former President Donald Trump, according to reports from The Daily Mail and The Hill. We found no public evidence of other donations.
label: refutes

claim: “It has just come out that Democrats in Washington and the Democrat Governor’s Office of North Carolina (Roy Cooper) were blocking people and money from coming into North Carolina.”
evidence: North Carolina’s Democratic governor, Roy Cooper, said Sept. 29 that 550 members of the state National Guard had deployed, 24 shelters had opened and more than 1,600 state transportation employees and contract crews were working to clear roads. | Coopersigned a $273 million Helene relief packageOct. 9 and has also encouraged people to donate to the state’s disaster relief fund. | A right-wing outlet published leaked emails from Blue Cross Blue Shield of North Carolina employees telling their colleagues not to travel to western NC to deliver donations or look at the devastation, citing the governor’s office. The company made this request because roads were impassable and rescue operations were in progress there.
label: refutes

claim: “Hurricane Nadine” was on a path to hit Florida on Oct. 10.
evidence: As of Oct. 12, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s National Hurricane Center had not reported that a storm called Nadine was developing near the U.S. | Nadine is the next name on the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s 2024 list of Atlantic tropical cyclone names.
label: refutes

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris’ “60 Minutes” interview may be “a major Campaign Finance Violation.”
evidence: Political experts told PolitiFact the argument that Vice President Kamala Harris’ "60 minutes" interview violated campaign finance laws is far-fetched and baseless. | A video clip previewing Harris’ interview and the full aired interview showed different responses from Harris on a question about U.S.-Israel relations. But a media ethics expert said it’s common for broadcast news outlets to edit interviews this way because of time constraints.
label: refutes

claim: “Dave McCormick is fully against abortion.”
evidence: Republican Dave McCormick expressed inconsistent positions on exceptions to abortion laws during his 2022 run for U.S. Senate. During a 2022 debate, said he supported exceptions for the mother’s life in "rare instances" but didn’t mention exceptions for rape and incest. | McCormick now says he would not support a national abortion ban, and he supports exceptions for rape, incest and to save the pregnant woman’s life. | McCormick said abortion laws should be left to states.
label: uncertain

claim: Republican state Senate candidate Ashlee Adams “campaigned for Mark Robinson and his radical agenda.”
evidence: Democratic North Carolina Senate candidate Terence Everitt made this claim in a television ad. | Mark Robinson, the state’s lieutenant governor, has called for more abortion restrictions. | Neither Everitt nor the North Carolina Democratic Party produced any photos or video of Adams campaigning for Robinson or endorsing his views.
label: refutes

claim: “Univision accidentally shows that Kamala Harris is reading from a teleprompter live on air.”
evidence: Vice President Kamala Harris spoke Oct. 10 at a town hall on Univision in Las Vegas. | A teleprompter with words on it was seen in a short video clip shared online, but the Univision moderator and news president said the words were in Spanish and meant for the moderator, not Harris. | After the words disappeared from the teleprompter, Harris continued her answer without pause for another three minutes.
label: refutes

claim: U.S. Sen. Sherrod Brown “supported allowing puberty blockers and sex-change surgeries for minor children.”
evidence: Asked about a Senate bill that proposed banning gender-affirming care, Sen. Sherrod Brown, D-Ohio, said he "will never agree with anyone that wants to bring politics into the family situation with health care." | Brown was one of nine senators who signed a March 31, 2023, letter to President Joe Biden, asking his administration to take executive action to protect access to gender-affirming care. | Gender-affirming refers to an individualized health care model that prioritizes encouraging and supporting a person’s gender identity — it is more than puberty blockers and surgery. Surgical procedures among minors are rare.
label: uncertain

claim: 2023 FEMA webinar shows the agency is prioritizing its relief efforts around LGBTQ+ people
evidence: The Federal Emergency Management Administration does not distribute aid based on gender identity or sexual orientation. | A FEMA-hosted March 2023 panel discussion titled, "Helping LGBTQIA+ Survivors Before Disasters: Preparedness and Mitigation Considerations," involved FEMA employees and non-FEMA experts and focused on improving disaster preparedness in LGBTQ+ communities, not FEMA’s general disaster response. | FEMA has held other webinars focused on specific communities such as older Americans, people with disabilities and faith groups.
label: refutes

claim: North Carolina’s new voting rules in response to Hurricane Helene amount to “cheating” or “stealing.”
evidence: The North Carolina General Assembly voted unanimously to change election rules to make in-person and mail voting easier in counties affected by Hurricane Helene. | The change in state law was similar to changes approved unanimously a day earlier by the bipartisan North Carolina State Board of Elections. | The Board of Elections has a Democratic majority; the General Assembly has a Republican majority. The changes were done publicly and apply to all voters in those counties, not just ones from one party.
label: refutes

claim: The government gave $3,500 debit cards to immigrants while giving only $750 to Hurricane Helene victims.
evidence: During an Oct. 2 speech, Vice President Kamala Harris said the Federal Emergency Management Agency is providing $750 in immediate aid to people affected by Hurricane Helene. In the same speech, she also said that FEMA is providing "tens of thousands more dollars" for home repairs and hotel costs. | A New York City program gives prepaid debit cards to migrant families sheltering in city hotels to spend on food and baby supplies for four weeks. The amount of money varies by family size, but is much less than $3,500 per person. For example, a family of four with two 10-year-olds would receive $1,267 for 28 days.
label: refutes

claim: “Arizona was safe” when she moved to the state in 1994, but has become “unsafe.”
evidence: In Arizona, both violent crime generally and murder specifically have declined by more than 40% since 1994.
label: refutes

claim: An image shows a child affected by recent hurricanes in the United States.
evidence: This image is computer generated.
label: refutes

claim: “We have cut the flow of fentanyl by half.”
evidence: Fentanyl seizures have more than doubled under the Biden-Harris administration, federal data shows. But that doesn’t confirm that the amount of fentanyl flowing into the U.S. has been cut in half. | Fentanyl seizure data tells us only how much fentanyl was stopped from entering the U.S., not how much entered. | One drug policy expert said a rise in seizures generally signals that more fentanyl is entering the U.S. Another expert said the data could be interpreted either way: as more coming in, or as less coming in.
label: refutes

claim: “Hurricane Nadine was a catastrophic Category 5 hurricane that struck Central America and the Bahamas in October 2024.”
evidence: Hurricane Nadine didn’t exist as of Oct. 10, though the next storm could have that name. Text describing a Hurricane Nadine in the past tense came from a website on which users write fictional articles about hurricanes.
label: refutes

claim: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz gave a college football crowd “the bird.”
evidence: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz pointed at the crowd at a recent college football game; he didn’t give fans "the bird."
label: refutes

claim: Says Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz was “banned from future games for flipping off the fans.”
evidence: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz wasn’t banned from future college football games. That claim originated on a self-described satire site. | He also didn’t raise his middle finger at fans; he was pointing.
label: refutes

claim: Image shows the projected trajectory for a Hurricane Nadine is “the same path as Helene.”
evidence: This image is from news coverage prior to Hurricane Helene and shows the projected trajectory of the storm when it was still a potential tropical cyclone. | The next hurricane could be called Nadine but the National Hurricane Center was monitoring no such storm as of Oct. 10.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows “people attempting to flee Florida & Hurricane Milton.”
evidence: This footage predates Hurricane Milton and shows flooding in September in Mumbai.
label: refutes

claim: “Two weeks ago 100 GOP lawmakers voted against additional FEMA funding.”
evidence: A stopgap funding bill passed by Congress Sept. 25 included $20 billion for the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s Disaster Relief Fund. But it was a much broader funding bill that also included money for many other federal programs. | In the Senate, 18 Republicans voted against the bill, and in the House, 82 did. Some Republicans said they opposed the bill for reasons unrelated to FEMA funding.
label: supports

claim: Says Democratic opponent Tammy Baldwin "gave stimulus checks to illegals."
evidence: Immigrants in the country illegally were not eligible for stimulus checks under the American Rescue Plan. | The American Rescue Plan required people receiving stimulus checks to have valid Social Security numbers.
label: refutes

claim: Patents dating back to the 1800s show that people can control the weather.
evidence: Meteorologists and atmospheric science experts told PolitiFact that they knew of no technology that lets anyone control the weather or create a hurricane, and they denied that a viral list of patents proved weather control is possible. | We investigated three patents on the list, and they didn’t show humans can control weather features such as hurricanes. | Patents can be filed for inventions that are impractical and products that never get made.
label: refutes

claim: U.S. Sen. Sherrod Brown voted to “allow transgender biological men to compete in girls’ sports.”
evidence: Sen. Sherrod Brown, D-Ohio, voted against two failed amendments to broader funding bills. The amendments would have stripped federal funding from schools and colleges that allowed transgender girls and women to compete in sports matching their gender identity; they did not dictate athletic eligibility. | Federal law rarely dictates who is eligible for specific sports.
label: refutes

claim: "Los 750 dólares que nuestra generosa administración ha ofrecido a las víctimas del huracán Helene son un PRÉSTAMO! Tienen un año para devolverlo".
evidence: La Agencia Federal para el Manejo de Emergencias de Estados Unidos (FEMA, por sus siglas en inglés) provee $750 bajo el programa de "Asistencia para Necesidades Graves", para que la gente pueda comprar alimentos, agua y otros suministros de emergencia. | Estos pagos no son préstamos que deban devolverse, según la agencia.
label: refutes

claim: "Teachers and nurses and firefighters are paying a higher tax rate than billionaires and the biggest corporations."
evidence: Under current law, the 25 highest-earning billionaires paid a 16% tax rate on average, estimates show, while the top 1% of taxpayers paid an average rate north of 25.6%. | More than 91% of households earning from $50,000 to $100,000 a year — the category that includes most teachers, firefighters and nurses — paid effective tax rates of 15% or less, often much less. | One study of 342 U.S. corporations found they pay an effective tax rate of 14.1%, which is a higher rate than most, though not all, middle-income households pay.
label: uncertain

claim: “Taylor Swift blames Instagram for losing millions of followers after Harris endorsement: ‘It must be a glitch!”
evidence: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.
label: refutes

claim: “FEMA is supposed to help out white people last for the purpose of ‘equity.’ … It’s literally on the FEMA website.”
evidence: The Federal Emergency Management Agency’s website doesn’t say it’s supposed to help white people last. It says that federal law requires FEMA assistance "to be delivered in an equitable manner without discrimination on the grounds of race, color, religion, nationality, sex, age, disability, language accessibility or economic status."
label: refutes

claim: “They create hurricanes via cloud seeding” and “direct them where they want the Hurricane to go!”
evidence: Cloud seeding, used to increase rain or snow in drought-stricken areas by injecting silver iodide into clouds, is the most common weather modification program in use in the U.S. | The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration once used cloud seeding in a decadeslong project to try to lessen the intensity of hurricanes, but the project was ended in 1983 after mixed results. | There are no weather modification projects that can create or modify hurricanes, weather officials and experts said.
label: refutes

claim: Says Wisconsin GOP U.S. Senate candidate Eric Hovde "brags about being in the 1%."
evidence: Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee held onto a quote from 12 years ago to use in an attack ad. | Wisconsin Republican senatorial candidate Eric Hovde campaign does not deny the claim but deflects onto his opponent, Democratic U.S. Sen. Tammy Baldwin.
label: supports

claim: The U.S. government is offering Americans loans to pay for flights out of Lebanon while they have been flying Israeli citizens out of Israel on chartered flights for a year “on our dime.”
evidence: Federal law requires U.S. citizens who have been evacuated abroad to reimburse their transportation costs. | The roughly 1,500 Americans who left Israel on chartered planes after Hamas’ Oct. 7, 2023, attack signed an agreement to repay the government before they departed. | More than 1,000 Americans have left Lebanon on U.S.-organized flights since the Israeli military began its ground invasion of southern Lebanon. A State Department spokesperson said the travel costs on U.S.-organized flights out of Lebanon to Turkey would not exceed $283 per person.
label: refutes

claim: A Republican representative posted a response to the vice presidential debate before it happened.
evidence: This post isn’t from an authentic Republican representative.
label: refutes

claim: Hurricane Milton is part of Tampa’s plan to become a “15-minute city.”
evidence: A National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration official told PolitiFact that human weather modification did not cause Hurricane Milton. | The "15-minute city" is an urban planning concept for designing cities to let residents meet basic needs with a short walk or bike ride from their homes. It has been the target of conspiracy theories about other disasters, including the 2023 Hawaii wildfires. | Tampa officials are working to address the city’s transportation problems, including reducing commute times, but this is unconnected to the hurricane.
label: refutes

claim: “FEMA is closing roads and bridges and causing gridlock traffic during evacuations from Hurricane Milton.”
evidence: Florida residents evacuated in advance of Hurricane Milton, causing traffic jams along highways in the Tampa Bay region. | State officials opened highway shoulders to vehicle traffic and suspended tolls. | FEMA confirmed it had no role in traffic control.
label: refutes

claim: Taylor Swift “admits to having done immoral things with Diddy in the past to gain fame.”
evidence: This claim is unfounded. | We found no credible evidence, such as news reporting, public statements or interview footage to corroborate the claim that Taylor Swift confessed to something "immoral" with Sean "Diddy" Combs.
label: refutes

claim: “Taylor Swift’s manager confirms: ‘Ticket sales are dead after Harris endorsement backlash.”
evidence: This didn’t happen. The purported quote originated on a self-described satire site.
label: refutes

claim: Hurricane Milton article is evidence they "control and plan these storms."
evidence: An article describing Hurricane Milton’s path and effects in past tense originated on a "Hypothetical Hurricanes" wiki page that lets weather enthusiasts create articles and graphics for fictional storm seasons. | The wiki page about the fictional Milton was deleted because of misinformation concerns, the site’s administrator said. | The name "Milton" had been planned by the World Meteorological Organization as one of 2024’s named storms. It replaced Michael, a storm that hit Florida in 2018, on the rotating list of storm names in 2019.
label: refutes

claim: Alexa’s answers to questions about Hurricane Helene prove the storm was “artificially created” or the result of “cloud seeding”
evidence: Experts told PolitiFact Hurricane Helene was a natural disaster. It was not formed through weather modification, and there are no projects that can modify or create hurricanes. | When we asked Amazon about the responses seen in the social media posts, a spokesperson responded by saying, "These answers are clearly incorrect and we are working to resolve this issue." | We did not get the same responses from Alexa and when asked the same questions, Alexa replied with, "Sorry, I don’t have an answer for that," or, "I don’t know that one," or ""Hmmm, I don’t know that."
label: refutes

claim: Video shows “geoengineering happening” as Hurricane Milton approaches Florida.
