claim: El 31 de julio de 2024 confirmaron el fallecimiento del expresidente Donald Trump en un accidente de helicóptero.
evidence: El expresidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, no falleció el 31 de julio en un accidente de helicóptero. Ese día él tuvo varios eventos públicos y desde entonces ha escrito en su red social Truth Social. | PolitiFact no encontró reportes verídicos de medios que confirmen su muerte o de que haya tenido un accidente de helicóptero.
label: refutes

claim: Biden Executive Order 14019 “requires our taxpayer-funded federal agencies to violate the Hatch Act and engage in illegal vote harvesting.”
evidence: The National Voter Registration Act, passed in 1993, states that voter registration agencies may include federal offices. | Executive Order 14019 states that when agencies carry out the order, all applicable laws must be followed. | The order does not command federal agencies to collect ballots.
label: refutes

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris “was born in Canada.”
evidence: Vice President Kamala Harris was born in 1964 in Oakland, California. | Harris lived in Canada from ages 12 to 18. She moved back to the United States after finishing high school.
label: refutes

claim: Switzerland “no longer recognizes Islam as an official religion.”
evidence: Switzerland banned full face coverings such as burqas, but it didn’t disacknowledge Islam.
label: refutes

claim: “Netflix loses 6 million subscribers within hours of donation announcement.”
evidence: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.
label: refutes

claim: “Estados Unidos decide INVADIR VENEZUELA”.
evidence: El Presidente Joe Biden pidió transparencia en los resultados de las elecciones de Venezuela. Pero él no ha dicho que Estados Unidos invadirá a Venezuela. | Los departamentos de Defensa de EE.UU. y de Estado le dijeron a PolitiFact que esta declaración es falsa.
label: refutes

claim: President Joe Biden “killed his first wife.”
evidence: President Joe Biden’s first wife, Nealia, died in a car crash in 1972 in Hockessin, Delaware. | Biden was in Washington, D.C., at the time.
label: refutes

claim: Kamala Harris was “Indian all the way, and then all of a sudden, she made a turn and she went, she became a Black person.”
evidence: In a contentious appearance at the National Association of Black Journalists annual conference in Chicago, former President Donald Trump argued with moderators over their questions and opened the conversation accusing Vice President Kamala Harris, the Democrats’ presumptive presidential nominee, of recently becoming Black. When asked whether he agreed with some Republicans characterizing Harris as a "DEI hire," Trump launched into an unwieldy attack, claiming Harris had always promoted being Indian and that he "didn’t know" whether she was Black. "She
label: refutes

claim: "Donald Trump intends to cut Social Security."
evidence: In his earlier campaigns and before he was a politician, Trump said about a half dozen times that he’s open to major overhauls of Social Security, including cuts and privatization. Most recently, in a March 2024 CNBC interview, Trump said of entitlement programs such as Social Security, "There’s a lot you can do in terms of entitlements, in terms of cutting." | However, Trump quickly walked that statement back, and his CNBC comment stands at odds with essentially everything else Trump has said during the 2024 presidential campaign. | Trump’s campaign website says that not "a single penny" should be cut from Social Security, and he’s repeated similar lines in campaign rallies.
label: uncertain

claim: “Even before the pandemic, America went into a manufacturing recession.”
evidence: There is no official definition for when an industrial sector goes into recession, but by two common metrics — employment and output — U.S. manufacturing tipped negatively starting in early 2019, Trump’s third year in office. | Although manufacturing employment rose fairly robustly for the first two years of Trump’s term, this job growth stalled in his third year and fell slightly before the pandemic hit. | Even more notable, economists say, is that manufacturing output, by two separate metrics, fell modestly but consistently following its 2018 peak.
label: supports

claim: Video shows that “JD Vance endorses Project 2025.”
evidence: A video shared by Kamala Harris’ presidential campaign on X does not show Republican vice presidential nominee Sen. JD Vance endorsing Project 2025.It was recorded in 2021, before Project 2025 existed. | Democrats have linked Project 2025 to former President Donald Trump when attacking its proposals, but the Heritage Foundation-produced guide is neither an official Trump campaign position nor the Republican Party platform. | Vance has expressed support from some, but not all, of the ideas promoted in Project 2025. Trump and Vance have rebutted claims that they support it.
label: refutes

claim: "Kamala just launched her presidential campaign on RuPaul's Drag Race."
evidence: Several news outlets reported Vice President Kamala Harris’ appearance on "RuPaul’s Drag Race" was recorded weeks before she announced she was running for president. | Harris launched her presidential campaign at an event in Wilmington, Delaware.
label: refutes

claim: Says Kamala Harris tweeted, “It’s BLACK LIVES MATTER, not ‘Biden Loves Minors!’”
evidence: This is a fabricated X post.
label: refutes

claim: Says Kamala Harris proposed on X that “we have the next debate at a venue Donald Trump feels more comfortable: Jeffrey Epstein’s townhouse.”
evidence: This isn’t a real X post from Vice President Kamala Harris.
label: refutes

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris “endorsed free taxpayer-funded government health care for all illegal aliens.”
evidence: Republicans hoping to portray presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Kamala Harris as extreme on immigration say she wanted to give immigrants in the country illegally access to free health benefits paid for by taxpayers. | Harris has supported giving immigrants who are in the country illegally access to health coverage through her 2019 Medicare for All plan, but she hasn’t said it would be free for them or that it would be funded by taxpayers.
label: uncertain

claim: Sen. JD Vance is “known for his obsession with couches.”
evidence: Republican vice presidential nominee Sen. JD Vance did not write in his bestselling memoir, "Hillbilly Elegy," about having a sexual encounter with a couch. | The false claim that he did surfaced on social media in a satirical post. | Illinois Democrat Gov. JB Pritzker amplified the claim on television but provided no more evidence to support the claim.
label: refutes

claim: Este video muestra un robo de votos en la elección del 2024 en Venezuela.
evidence: Las autoridades electorales de Venezuela declararon a Nicolás Maduro el ganador de las elecciones presidenciales de 2024 del país. La oposición cuestionó los resultados. | Publicaciones en redes sociales comparten erróneamente un video diciendo que muestra hombres robando urnas electorales. Los hombres cargaban unidades de aire acondicionado de ventana.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows “thousands of Christians in France gathered to pray after Olympics opening mocked Jesus Christ.”
evidence: This video was taken in 2022, so it predates the Paris Olympics. It shows thousands of people gathered at the Sanctuary of Our Lady Lourdes in Lourdes, France, for the Feast of the Assumption, which commemorates the belief that Mary, the mother of Jesus, ascended to heaven after she died. | Some social media users shared another video claiming it showed a "worship service" following the Paris Olympics opening ceremony. But this video was taken in May.
label: refutes

claim: Project 2025 would end gay marriage.
evidence: As it is outlined in a 900-page document titled "Mandate for Leadership," Project 2025 includes no proposal to eliminate same-sex marriage. | The document refers to heterosexual families as "ideal" and calls for the protection of faith-based federal grant recipients who do not support same-sex marriage. | Project 2025 is a "presidential transition project" led by the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank. Its contributors include a number of former Trump administration advisers, but former President Donald Trump has sought to distance himself from the plan. He has not advocated banning same-sex marriage during his 2024 presidential campaign.
label: refutes

claim: “Netflix stock tumbles almost 40%” after the company donated to Kamala Harris’ campaign.
evidence: The post originated from a satire website, which alluded to a real $7 million donation made by Reed Hastings, Netflix co-founder and executive chairman, to a super PAC supporting Vice President Kamala Harris’ presidential campaign. | Netflix itself did not donate to Harris’ campaign; corporations are barred from donating to federal elections.
label: refutes

claim: Vice President Kamala Harris is “calling for an end to the child tax credit.”
evidence: Vice President Kamala Harris has repeatedly expressed support for the child tax credit. | The Biden administration approved the 2021 American Rescue Plan, which expanded the child tax credit that year to $3,600 per child younger than 6, and $3,000 per child ages 6 to 17. The current amount is $2,000 per child, up to age 16. | The administration has pressured Congress to make the more generous credits permanent.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows “several masked men stormed a local voting station and stole the ballot boxes” in Venezuela’s 2024 election.
evidence: Venezuela’s electoral authorities on July 29 declared Nicolás Maduro the winner of the nation’s 2024 presidential election. The opposition is questioning the results. | A viral social media video claiming to show men stealing ballot boxes is wrong. The men are carrying air conditioning window units, not boxes of ballots.
label: refutes

claim: Kamala Harris “wants to defund the police.”
evidence: Calls by some liberals to "defund the police" followed a police officer’s murder of George Floyd. "Defund" is not an official legal term and can mean anything from closing a police department to diverting some of its budget to social services. | In 2020, then-Sen. Kamala Harris, D-Calif., called for "reimagining" public safety. But she didn’t explicitly call for shuttering police departments. | Harris has said police agencies are necessary and has called for more law enforcement funding.
label: uncertain

claim: “100 million ballots (Democrats) prefilled now have the wrong name.”
evidence: There are no official ballots for the general election yet. | The 2024 Democratic presidential nominee will be determined in a virtual nominating process ahead of the Democratic National Convention in August. | State deadlines for receiving the presidential nominee’s name for ballot printing generally fall after that.
label: refutes

claim: "Mike Pence endorsed Kamala Harris.”
evidence: Former Vice President Mike Pence said in March he isn’t endorsing Donald Trump for president and reiterated that in a July podcast. | Pence has not endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris, the Democrats’ presumptive nominee, and doesn’t plan to, said Alison Holcomb, a spokesperson for Advancing American Freedom, a conservative advocacy group that Pence founded.
label: refutes

claim: Kamala Harris said, “Today we celebrate the Olympics. Because Olympians are Olympic.”
evidence: Vice President Kamala Harris did not say this quote about the Olympics, her campaign spokesperson said.
label: refutes

claim: Kamala Harris “supported abolishing ICE.”
evidence: As a U.S. senator in 2018, Kamala Harris criticized the Trump administration’s immigration policies, including a policy that led to family separations at the border. | In that context, Harris said U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s function should be reexamined and that "we need to probably even think about starting from scratch." | But Harris didn’t say there shouldn’t be immigration enforcement. In 2018, Harris also said U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement had a role and should exist.
label: refutes

claim: Rose Garden video shows that President Joe Biden was taller when he emerged from July 24 Oval Office speech.
evidence: The video of President Joe Biden walking out to the White House’s Rose Garden was shot at a lower angle. Because the camera was pointing up at Biden, it made him look taller. | In the video, Biden was standing a few steps in front of first lady Jill Biden, making him appear bigger because he was closer to the camera. In another photo from that day, the Bidens were standing beside each other, and their height difference was less exaggerated.
label: refutes

claim: “Today, America has record energy production and we are energy independent.”
evidence: Overall U.S. energy production is at a record high, and, by some definitions, the U.S. is energy independent. | However, in one key regard, the U.S. is not energy independent: The U.S. is a net importer of crude oil, which keeps the U.S. and its economy beholden to overseas developments.
label: supports

claim: "Taylor Swift y Beyoncé se unen para un concierto épico en apoyo a Kamala Harris!".
evidence: Taylor Swift y Beyoncé no anunciaron el 24 de julio un concierto para recaudar fondos para la campaña presidencial de Kamala Harris.
label: refutes

claim: ABC News reporter said “government tried to kill” former President Donald Trump.
evidence: ABC News Chief Justice Correspondent Pierre Thomas did not say the "government tried to kill former President Trump," as shortened social media videos claim. | In a report that aired July 24 on "Good Morning America," he used the word "gunman" several times and named the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, whom the Secret Service killed. | FBI Director Christopher Wray said the continuing investigation so far has not found that Crooks had any accomplices in the July 13 assassination attempt against Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania.
label: refutes

claim: Thomas Matthew Crooks worked for BlackRock "in the past" and BlackRock owned the building Crooks stood on when he shot at the Trump campaign rally.
evidence: Thomas Matthew Crooks appeared briefly in a 2022 BlackRock Inc., ad about teachers’ retirement plans. He and other students in the background were not paid, BlackRock said. | County records show American Glass Research Inc. owns the building from which Crooks fired the shots that killed one person and injured three, including former President Donald Trump. | A BlackRock spokesperson said the company neither owns nor has real estate funds invested in the building.
label: refutes

claim: Bruce Willis murió, 23 de julio de 2024.
evidence: Bruce Willis no ha muerto.
label: refutes

claim: Financial advisory company Austin Private Wealth shorted 12 million shares of Trump Media July 12, the day before former President Donald Trump’s attempted assassination.
evidence: Austin Private Wealth, an investment adviser, said the amount of shorted Trump Media shares reported in its July 12 filing was incorrect. The accurate holding amount was 1,200 shares, not 12 million.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows President Joe Biden’s July 24 address is “either CGI or a mask.”
evidence: This video was altered.
label: refutes

claim: Videos show Jill Biden alone in Paris and at White House with Joe Biden at the same time.
evidence: A viral video shared on X doesn’t show first lady Jill Biden in Washington, D.C., and Paris at the same time. | Biden was at the White House where President Joe Biden gave a primetime speech about exiting the presidential race. Soon after, she left on a flight for Paris to lead the U.S. Olympic delegation.
label: refutes

claim: Imágenes muestran a la subdirectora del FBI Janeen DiGuiseppi sentada detrás del expresidente Donald Trump durante su intento de asesinato.
evidence: En 2023, Janeen DiGuiseppi fue ascendida a subdirectora de la Oficina de Amenazas Internas del FBI. | Un portavoz del FBI dijo que una mujer que aparece en publicaciones virales en redes sociales no es DiGuiseppi. | DiGuiseppi no asistió al mitin del expresidente Donald Trump en Butler, Pensilvania, según el FBI.
label: refutes

claim: Says Bruce Willis died, as of July 23, 2024.
evidence: Bruce Willis isn’t dead.
label: refutes

claim: Says Taylor Swift “announced a fund raising concert with Beyoncé in support of Harris” on July 23.
evidence: Taylor Swift didn’t announce on July 23 a fundraiser for Vice President Kamala Harris.

claim: Image shows former President Donald Trump golfing July 23 with “no wound. No bandage.”
evidence: These images are from a video shared July 23 on YouTube, but the footage — former President Donald Trump playing a round with professional golfer Bryson DeChambeau — was taken before the July 13 assassination attempt.
label: refutes

claim: President Joe Biden is stepping down from the 2024 presidential race because he’s dead.
evidence: President Joe Biden didn’t die, but social media users are claiming he’s been dead since 2018 and that’s why he recently withdrew from the 2024 presidential race.
label: refutes

claim: "Muere la madre de Michelle Obama, deja herencia a 'Mi hijo Michael'".
evidence: La madre de Michelle Obama, fallecida en mayo, no mencionó a su hija como mujer transgénero en su testamento. | El origen de esta afirmación surgió de una página web que se autodenomina como sátira.
label: refutes

claim: Usha Vance, wife of Republican vice presidential nominee JD Vance, posted on X that Vice President Kamala Harris was “absolutely a DEI hire.”
evidence: We found no credible news reports that Usha Vance, wife of Republican vice presidential nominee and Ohio Sen. claim: Photo shows “Thomas Matthew Crooks wearing a quipá.”
evidence: The person in this photo isn’t Thomas Matthew Crooks, according to the synagogue that posted it in February on its Facebook page.

evidence: Rep. Sheila Jackson Lee, D-Texas, died July 19 at age 74. Although a cause of death has not been publicly reported, Jackson Lee said in June that she had been diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. | We searched using Google and Nexis and found no reliable news reports connecting Jackson Lee's death to Secret Service oversight work or the Trump rally shooting. | During July 22 congressional testimony, then-Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle offered lawmakers condolences for Jackson Lee’s death. That sparked claims linking Jackson Lee’s death to oversight of the U.S. Secret Service.
label: refutes

claim: As of July 23, 2024, “Trump has announced he won’t debate Kamala Harris.”
evidence: The claim isn’t accurate. During a July 23 call with reporters hosted by the Republican National Committee, Trump said he’d be "absolutely" willing to debate Harris "multiple times."

claim: Starbucks was an “official sponsor of the RNC.”
evidence: Starbucks Corp. was not an official sponsor of the Republican National Convention. | The company worked with the Milwaukee 2024 Host Committee, a liaison between the city and the Republican National Committee, to give coffee to first responders including EMTs and firefighters.

claim: "Kamala Harris no es elegible para postularse para la presidencia. Ninguno de sus padres eran ciudadanos estadounidenses natos cuando ella nació".
evidence: La vicepresidenta Kamala Harris nació en 1964 en Oakland, California. | La 14ª Enmienda de la Constitución de EE.UU. establece que son ciudadanos los nacidos en el país. | Según el Artículo II de la Constitución, sólo los ciudadanos nacidos en Estados Unidos pueden ser elegidos presidentes. Harris cumple ese requisito.

claim: “Michelle Obama’s mother dies, leaves inheritance to ‘my son Michael.’”
evidence: This claim originated on a self-described satire site. Michelle Obama’s mother, who died in May, didn’t out her daughter as a transgender woman in her will.

claim: Project 2025 calls for restricting “access to IVF and contraception.”
evidence: Project 2025, the 900-page conservative manual for the next Republican administration, doesn’t specifically recommend restrictions to in vitro fertilization, or IVF. | The manual also doesn’t call for restricting standard contraceptive methods, such as birth control pills or intrauterine devices. It does recommend restricting some emergency contraceptives from no-cost insurance coverage and defunding Planned Parenthood. | The document also has language that supports rights for fetuses and embryos, which legal experts said threatens family planning methods, including IVF and some forms of contraception.

claim: President Joe Biden appointed "Kamala Harris to be his border czar to deal with illegal immigration … Harris was put in charge of stopping illegal immigration."
evidence: In March 2021, President Joe Biden tasked Vice President Kamala Harris with working alongside officials in Guatemala, El Salvador and Honduras to address the issues driving people to leave those countries and come to the United States. | The Biden-Harris administration said it would focus on five key issues: economic insecurity, corruption, human rights, criminal gang violence and gender-based violence. | Border security and management is the Homeland Security secretary’s responsibility.
label: uncertain

claim: Images show FBI assistant director Janeen DiGuiseppi seated behind former President Donald Trump during his assassination attempt.
evidence: In 2023, Janeen DiGuiseppi was promoted to the role of FBI assistant director of the agency’s Insider Threat Office. | An FBI spokesperson said a woman shown in viral social media posts is not DiGuiseppi. | DiGuiseppi did not attend former President Donald Trump’s rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, an FBI statement to PolitiFact said.

claim: Fox News aired a chyron that said, “Kamala could be the oldest elected female president.”
evidence: This image was altered. Fox News didn’t air this chyron, a network spokesperson said.

claim: The absence of the presidential seal on President Joe Biden’s letter announcing his exit from the presidential race proves “this wasn’t Biden’s choice.”
evidence: President Joe Biden published the letter as a candidate and not for official presidential business, so the letter did not require a presidential seal. ​

claim: Photo shows Trump shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks was transgender.

evidence: President Joe Biden was the presumptive — not official — Democratic presidential nominee until he announced July 21 that he would be dropping out of the race. | The official nominee will be chosen either in the run-up to the Democratic National Convention that starts Aug. 19 or at the convention itself. | States set deadlines for receiving the names of presidential nominees so that ballots can be printed. evidence: Washington sent out ballots for its Aug. 6 statewide primary election, which does not include a presidential primary. Biden has since dropped out of the race and endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris. | Under Washington law, presidential candidates must be certified for the November ballot by Aug. 20, which falls before the Democratic nominee could be formally elected at the Democratic National Convention. Washington’s secretary of state will accept a letter from the Democratic National Committee attesting to the party’s alternate nominee, a spokesperson said.

claim: Former President Jimmy Carter “passed away Tuesday, July 23, at 01:34 am at his home in Plains, Georgia at the age of 99.”

claim: Project 2025 would “end Head Start.”

claim: Says former President Donald Trump said, “It took my entire ear off. The whole ear.”

evidence: In 2011, Donald Trump, as a private citizen, donated $5,000 to Kamala Harris’ California attorney general reelection campaign. evidence: This video is a deepfake. claim: Bill Gates is responsible for July 19 global tech outage.

He wasn’t shot during the rally itself, as Trump was — rather beforehand, and he decided to go speak anyway. | Though Donald Trump Jr. got that detail wrong in his attempt to relate the incident to what happened to his father, he’s largely right about the story.

claim: A photo shows proof of a bullet hole in Trump’s jacket.
evidence: Although the photo is authentic, it doesn’t show proof of a bullet in former President Donald Trump’s chest. | The apparent hole is a crease in a Secret Service agent’s jacket. claim: The Secret Service staged the July 13 shooting at Trump rally.

claim: Photo shows the Instagram account of shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks, with the bio, “In my quest to end Epsteins evil empire.”

Arizona State University’s president confirmed July 15 that the man in the video was not Thomas Matthew Crooks, the suspect in the July 13 Trump rally shooting. | In 2020, Crooks was a sophomore at Bethel Park High School in Pennsylvania.
label: refutes

claim: Photo shows Barron Trump on July 13, 2024, at Butler, Pennsylvania, rally.
evidence: The photo of Barron Trump in the Threads post was taken at a July 9 Trump campaign rally in Doral, Florida, four days before a gunman fired at former President Donald Trump. | We found no credible news reports, photos or video footage of Barron Trump attending the July 13 campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, where the gunman fired at his father. A letter that Donald Trump’s wife, Melania, wrote after the shooting did not say she and Barron had attended.
label: refutes

claim: Thomas Crooks “was a registered Democrat who voted for Clinton and Biden.”
evidence: The FBI confirmed that the individual who fired shots at Trump’s Pennsylvania rally was 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks. | Crooks would have been too young to vote in the 2016 or 2020 elections. | Pennsylvania voting records show that Crooks was a registered Republican.
label: refutes

claim: Photo shows Secret Service agents smiling while escorting Donald Trump offstage after assassination attempt.
evidence: The photo was altered. In the original photo, taken by Associated Press photojournalist Evan Vucci, the Secret Service agents weren’t smiling.
label: refutes

claim: Donald Trump escenificó el tiroteo en su mitin en Butler, Pensilvania.
evidence: Las autoridades sospechan que Thomas Matthew Cooks, de 20 años, fue el autor del tiroteo del 13 de julio en un mitin de campaña del expresidente Donald Trump en Butler, Pensilvania. | Trump resultó herido en el tiroteo, una persona murió y dos más fueron heridas gravemente. | Trump sangraba por la parte superior de la oreja derecha mientras los agentes del Servicio Secreto de Estados Unidos lo sacaron del escenario. El FBI está investigando el tiroteo, que tuvo miles de testigos, como un intento de asesinato.
label: refutes

claim: “The idea that there’s political violence or violence in America like this is just unheard of.”
evidence: Examples of political violence against U.S. presidents date back to Abraham Lincoln in 1865. | Lawmakers, presidents and political candidates have also been targeted. U.S. Rep. Gabby Giffords, D-Ariz., was injured in a 2011 shooting and Rep. Steve Scalise, R-La., was injured in a 2017 shooting. | The Jan. 6, 2021, assault on the U.S. Capitol is an example of political violence on a wider scale. Some rioters chanted to "hang" Vice President Mike Pence.
label: refutes

claim: Estas imágenes muestran a Thomas Matthew Crooks, el sospechoso del tiroteo en el mitin de Donald Trump.
evidence: Un hombre tomó falsamente la responsabilidad del intento de asesinato. | Él publicó una foto y un video de sí mismo diciendo que él fue el tirador en el mitin. | La publicación salió horas después de que la policía y oficiales locales confirmaran la muerte del sospechoso real.
label: refutes

claim: A photo from viral social media posts shows Trump rally shooting suspect Thomas Matthew Crooks.
evidence: An unnamed man falsely claimed responsibility for the attempted assassination. | He posted a photo and a video of himself saying he was the shooter at the rally. | The posts came hours after police and local officials confirmed the real shooting suspect was dead.
label: refutes

claim: Donald Trump staged the shooting at his rally in Butler, Pennsylvania.
evidence: Authorities suspect a July 13 shooting at a Butler, Pennsylvania, campaign rally — which killed one person, critically injured two others and left former President Donald Trump injured — was carried out by 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Cooks. | Trump bled from his upper right ear as Secret Service agents ushered him offstage; he pumped his fist to show he was OK. The FBI is investigating the shooting, which thousands of people witnessed, as an assassination attempt. | FBI Special Agent Kevin Rojek said it was surprising that the suspect had been able to fire multiple shots before Secret Service agents killed him. Rojek said a lengthy investigation is needed.
label: refutes

claim: “El que disparo Donald Trump, Mark Violets ha sido asesinado.”
evidence: El 14 de julio, el FBI identificó a Thomas Matthew Crooks, un hombre de 20 años de Bethel Park, Pennsylvania, como el sospechoso del tiroteo en el evento del expresidente Donald Trump en Butler, Pensilvania. | Un blogger de fútbol italiano, Marco Violi, negó en Instagram haber participado en el tiroteo. | Si ves algo que te hace preguntar: ¿es cierto?Mándanoslo por WhatsApp y nuestro equipo lo investigará, (813) 260-7595.
label: refutes

claim: “Butler Police confirm the shooter’s name is Mark Violets. He is a known Antifa extremist.”
evidence: On July 14, the FBI identified 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks of Bethel Park, Pennsylvania, as the shooting suspect at former President Donald Trump’s rall in Butler, Pennsylvania. | Italian sports blogger Marco Violi posted on Instagram denying any involvement in the shooting.
label: refutes

claim: “Trump rally shooter has been identified as 32-year-old California resident, Hank Pecker.”
evidence: The FBI identified the shooting suspect as Thomas Matthew Crooks, a 20-year-old from Bethel Park, Pennsylvania.
label: refutes

claim: "The Trump administration handed out taxpayer dollars to a foreign company. Hundreds of homes and farms were bulldozed, and over $500 million in taxpayer dollars were wasted preparing for Foxconn."
evidence: The Trump administration didn’t give taxpayer money to Foxconn — Wisconsin did. | Somewhere between 100 and 130 properties were demolished for the project — not "hundreds." | Yes, more than $500 million was spent, but officials say it also helped lead to a massive new investment by Microsoft Corp.
label: supports

claim: "Project 2025 eliminates OSHA and overtime wages.”
evidence: Project 2025, a conservative agenda proposed by a coalition of more than 100 organizations, calls for making sweeping changes to the federal government under the next Republican president. | Contrary to social media claims, the policy plan does not call to eliminate the Occupational Safety and Health Administration or banning overtime wages. | The plan does call for changes to some OSHA regulations and to overtime rules. Some changes, if enacted, could result in some people losing overtime protections.
label: refutes

claim: Lower insulin prices were the work of the Trump administration, not “Crooked Joe Biden. He had NOTHING to do with it.”
evidence: President Donald Trump continues to claim that he alone deserves credit for lowering insulin prices for seniors. | Though the Trump administration established a voluntary, temporary program lowering insulin costs for some older Americans on Medicare, the mandatory price caps implemented through Biden’s Inflation Reduction Act go significantly further. | Trump deserves some credit for lowering seniors’ drug costs, but his claim that Biden deserves none cannot be justified.
label: refutes

claim: BBC News published a graphic quoting President Joe Biden saying, “Let me say this as clearly and simply as I can: [inaudible].”
evidence: The original graphic published July 4 quoted President Joe Biden as saying, "I’m running."
label: refutes

claim: “Anyone on Social Security or Disability should know, Project 2025 totally eliminates all benefits.”
evidence: Project 2025’s operating document does not mention a plan to cut Social Security and disability benefits. | The document, consisting of policy proposals for Donald Trump to institute if he becomes president in 2025, calls to reform the federal government’s employee pay rate and benefits. | The plan also calls for changes to how veterans disability claims are managed, but it doesn't advocate for eliminating such benefits.
label: refutes

claim: List shows settlements Donald Trump made to 10- to 13-year-old victims of child sex crimes.
evidence: We found no evidence of these cases or settlements.
label: refutes

claim: CNN producer “caught on hot mic” commenting on Maxine Waters’ “wig problem.”
evidence: The post included a voice-over, not a CNN producer, commenting on the situation. | Don Lemon did not laugh at Maxine Waters. The video used a clip from 2018, and Lemon was fired from CNN in 2023.
label: refutes

claim: In 2020, “only nine NATO allies were spending 2%” of their GDP on defense. “This year, 23 will spend at least 2%.”
evidence: In response to instability in the Middle East and Russia’s illegal annexation of Crimea, NATO leaders agreed in 2014 to aim to commit 2% of their GDP to defense spending by 2024. | In 2020, nine NATO members spent at least 2% of their annual gross domestic product on defense, according to NATO data. In 2024, 23 NATO members will spend at least 2% of their GDP to build up their defenses, recent NATO data shows. | Experts warned against attributing member nations’ increased defense spending to any one cause or president, though multiple experts linked Russia’s 2022 invasion of Ukraine to the recent uptick in defense spending.
label: supports

claim: “(Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro) Mayorkas said, ‘Hey you don’t have to detain aggravated felons,’ those are rapists, child predators, you know, murderers.”
evidence: A September 2021 Department of Homeland Security memo prioritized for detention and deportation people who threatened public safety because of "serious criminal conduct." | The memo didn’t explicitly say "aggravated felons" should be a priority and said immigration officials should consider additional factors when determining whether someone convicted of a crime should be detained. | But immigration experts said people convicted of murder or rape — serious criminal conduct and aggravated felonies — would be considered an enforcement priority.
label: uncertain

claim: LGBTQ+ leaders sign World Economic Forum treaty to “Accept Pedophiles as 'Legally Protected Minority’”
evidence: This claim originated on The People’s Voice, a website that frequently publishes false information. | The 10-minute video in the post includes zero evidence to support the claim or details about what treaty or LGBTQ+ leaders it refers to. | PolitiFact could find no evidence such a treaty to "accept pedophiles as a legally protected minority" exists, and a World Economic Forum spokesperson said the claim is fabricated.
label: refutes

claim: Official Navy photographs show an unidentified flying object in the Arctic Ocean in 1971.
evidence: The U.S. Navy could not verify whether the photographs were official. | The former commanding officer of the USS Trepang II said he did not witness an unidentified flying object while aboard the ship in 1971.
label: refutes

claim: “Every single McDonald’s french fry comes exclusively from potatoes grown on Bill Gates-owned farmland.”
evidence: One farm that supplies potatoes to McDonald’s is owned by Bill Gates, the philanthropist and Microsoft Corp. co-founder, but it is not the sole supplier. The company’s websites in the U.S. and elsewhere list other potato suppliers.
label: refutes

claim: Black women in the U.S. are “three to four times more likely to die in connection with childbirth than other women."
evidence: The latest data shows that Black women in the U.S. have a maternal mortality rate of 49.5 for every 100,000 live births — nearly three times higher than their non-Hispanic white counterparts. | The U.S. has the highest maternal mortality rate among economically comparable nations, data shows, with an overall rate in 2022 of 22.3 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. | Reasons behind the country’s high maternal mortality numbers and its racial disparity, include a lack of health care coverage, no guaranteed paid parental leave, less robust postpartum care, and racial discrimination.
label: supports

claim: “Deadlines have passed in … Wisconsin” to replace President Joe Biden on the ballot.
evidence: Presidential and vice presidential candidates are placed on the ballot once parties certify their names to the Wisconsin Elections Commission. | The deadline for the parties to do so is Sept. 3, which has not passed. | That date is after the Democratic National Convention, and Democrats plan to nominate Biden even before the convention.
label: refutes

claim: Kamala Harris "co-sponsored, fully sponsored" the Green New Deal.
evidence: When senators introduced their version of the Green New Deal in February 2019, Harris was one of 11 Democrats who were original co-sponsors. | In a Medium post published the day the resolution was introduced, Harris wrote that she was "proud" to have signed on as an original Senate co-sponsor.
label: supports

claim: "Miami Dolphins QB Tua Tagovailoa” had a “front-row seat” reserved at Donald Trump’s Miami rally.
evidence: A photo shared on social media of a front-row seat reserved for Dolphins quarterback Tua Tagovailoa at Donald Trump’s July 9 Miami rally was altered. | The seat was reserved for Barron Trump, the former president’s 18-year-old son, a Daily Caller reporter’s original photo shows.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows Elon Musk saying Oreos are “satanic.”
evidence: This video was altered. Elon Musk didn’t say Oreos are satanic.
label: refutes

claim: “Elective abortions up to and including the moment of birth. Healthy, 9-month-year-old baby killed at the moment of birth. That’s what Jon Tester and the Democrats have voted for.”
evidence: In Montana’s Senate race, GOP candidate Tim Sheehy said his Democratic opponent, incumbent Sen. Jon Tester, supports abortion "up to and including the moment of birth." | Sheehy’s claim is based on Tester’s support for the proposed Women’s Health Protection Act. But his charge doesn’t hold up against the specifics of that legislation. | This claim is being used against other Democrats in various races.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows “huge green coloured meteor” on July 7, 2024, in Budapest, Hungary.
evidence: Details in the video signal it was originally taken in Hero’s Square in Budapest, Hungary, during a Feb. 16 protest. | There are no news reports of a fireball or meteor appearing in the sky during these protests or in July 7’s early morning hours. | Meteor experts pointed to signs that the meteor in the video is fake: it does not move in a straight line, is too slow and does not light up the surrounding sky.
label: refutes

claim: CNN reported July 3 that “Joe has decided to drop out of the 2024 Presidential race and will be replaced by Hunter Biden.”
evidence: As of July 9, neither President Joe Biden nor his campaign have announced that Biden is exiting the 2024 presidential race. | A CNN spokesperson told PolitiFact that CNN did not report on July 3 that Biden was dropping out, or that Hunter Biden would replace him. | In a July 8 letter to congressional Democrats and in multiple social media posts, Biden has reiterated that he will continue his reelection bid.
label: refutes

claim: “The New York Times has closed its main Threads account.”
evidence: A New York Times spokesperson said the newspaper didn’t deactivate its Threads account. | A technology news reporter at the paper said Instagram told him it took down the account "in error." It was later restored.
label: refutes

claim: “Officially; Lia Thomas has lost every title.”
evidence: Swimmer Lia Thomas didn’t lose "every title."
label: refutes

claim: Video shows tornado caused by Hurricane Beryl in July 2024.
evidence: Video footage showing a large tornado towering over a strip mall and other buildings was shared online before Hurricane Beryl formed as a tropical depression in June 2024. | We found footage filmed in Florida during Hurricane Matthew in 2016 that largely matched the footage being shared, but the Hurricane Matthew footage did not include a tornado.
label: refutes

claim: La compañía Fisher-Price creó un juguete "Ouija para niños”.
evidence: Un experto en inteligencia artificial le dijo a PolitiFact que la imagen del supuesto juguete tiene señales de ser falsa. | También encontramos que el video del juguete falso fue creado como sátira, por un usuario en TikTok.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows “Florida beach tornado” July 7, 2024
evidence: This is old footage. There was no tornado in Miami on July 7.
label: refutes

claim: Photo shows Mount Etna erupting in Sicily in July 2024.
evidence: The photo shows Mount Etna erupting in February 2021, not July 2024. | Mount Etna did erupt in July 2024, and the Catania Airport suspended operations only for a few hours. It reopened July 5.
label: refutes

claim: President Joe Biden had a “medical emergency on Air Force One” on July 5.
evidence: Evidence does not support the claim that President Joe Biden suffered a medical emergency aboard Air Force One July 5. | The press had full access to the plane during the flight and did not report a medical emergency. | A video shows Biden exiting the plane unassisted after it landed and greeting a military officer.
label: refutes

claim: The Associated Press reported “prosecutors are reconsidering bringing charges against former President Donald J. Trump on child rape and molestation charges.”
evidence: The Associated Press didn’t report this.
label: refutes

claim: Project 2025 mandates women carry “period passports” to “track their menstrual cycles” and “monitor pregnancies.”
evidence: This claim originated on a satirical X account. | Project 2025 is a policy agenda created by conservative groups in the hope that former President Donald Trump will enact it should he win the presidency in November. The agenda does not call for women to carry period passports.
label: refutes

claim: “Roundabouts are causing tornadoes.”
evidence: Roundabouts don’t cause tornadoes, according to a weather expert.
label: refutes

claim: A McDonald’s billboard said, “Hey crypto bro’s we are hiring.”
evidence: This image was altered. This isn’t an authentic photo of a McDonald’s billboard.
label: refutes

claim: “In official capacity, Biden orders DOJ to arrest 6 justices of SCOTUS.”
evidence: President Joe Biden didn’t order the arrest of six U.S. Supreme Court justices.
label: refutes

claim: La comunidad de hispanos se puede beneficiar de una "Nueva ley de prosperidad nacional elimina hasta 47,000 en deudas de tarjetas de crédito".
evidence: Un portavoz del Servicio Interno de Impuestos de Estados Unidos le dijo a PolitiFact que no existe ninguna ley que elimine las deudas de tarjetas de crédito. | Tampoco encontramos reportes verídicos de una nueva ley llamada "prosperidad nacional". | El video usa falsamente la imágen de la presentadora de Univision, Ilia Calderón y de los periodistas de Telemundo, Octavio Pulido y Javier Vega.
label: refutes

claim: Photo shows “Roman tidal baths in Malta, still at sea level after thousands of years!”
evidence: Pools in Sliema, Malta, are referred to as Roman baths but were constructed in Victorian times, according to the Maltese government.
label: refutes

claim: “Disney and Google bought the rights to the first King James Bible.”
evidence: This story originated on a satire site.
label: refutes

claim: "For 18 months under President Trump, not a single American was harmed in Afghanistan.”
evidence: Defense Department data shows an 18-month stretch with no U.S. service member combat deaths in Afghanistan after then-President Donald Trump and the Taliban reached a deal to end the war in late February 2021. | That includes seven months of President Joe Biden’s administration. | There were three service members wounded in combat and four troops who died in noncombat-related deaths during the Trump administration after the deal with the Taliban was reached.
label: refutes

claim: C-sections are coded as abortions in hospitals.
evidence: A cesarean section, commonly known as a C-section, is a surgical procedure that delivers a fetus through incisions in the mother's abdomen. | C-sections have their own procedural codes for tracking and insurance that cover this type of delivery. These codes do not mention abortion. C-sections can be risky and are not typically used to facilitate abortions, health experts said.
label: refutes

claim: "Huracán Beryl pasado por la isla Canarias todo quedo bajo Agua y Horacio por todo la isla afectada ".
evidence: El huracán Beryl rompió un récord al formarse como categoría 5 en el Atlántico en cuatro días y a principios de la temporada de huracanes. | Los videos en la publicación en Threads no son del huracán Beryl pasando por las Islas Canarias. | El Centro Nacional de Huracanes de Estados Unidos no reportó que Beryl pasó por las Islas Canarias. Sus boletines refieren el paso del huracán por el sureste del Caribe, Jamaica, las islas Caimán y próximamente el Golfo de México.
label: refutes

claim: “Riley Gaines won $10 million against Whoopi Goldberg for defaming her reputation.”
evidence: This claim originated on a self-described satire site.
label: refutes

claim: Activistas de Just Stop Oil "han rociado con pintura naranja el avión de Taylor Swift, en el aeródromo privado de Stansted, en el Reino Unido".
evidence: Los activistas pintaron dos aviones después de que la cantante Taylor Swift aterrizara en el aeropuerto de Stansted, Reino Unido, pero no vandalizaron el jet privado de la cantante estadounidense.
label: refutes

claim: "Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 returns after 10-year mystery"
evidence: March 8, 2014, Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 disappeared off air traffic control radar. Later evidence signaled it likely crashed into the Indian Ocean. | Despite an extensive three-year search, the plane has still not been recovered, but debris confirmed to be part of the plane has been found. | The flight has not returned.
label: refutes

claim: “En la última conferencia médica en Estados Unidos, el Dr. Juan Rivera presentó una nueva terapia que ha sido validada y demostrada efectiva para manejar el tinnitus”.
evidence: El Dr. Juan Rivera no presentó una nueva terapia para el tinnitus, la imagen en Facebook fue sacada de contexto. | Una portavoz del Dr. Rivera le dijo a PolitiFact que la publicación es fraudulenta. | El Instituto Nacional de la Sordera y Otros Trastornos de la Comunicación dice que actualmente no existe una cura para el tinnitus.
label: refutes

claim: "President Zelenskyy’s wife orders 4 million dollar Bugatti” in Paris with U.S. tax money.
evidence: A claim that Ukrainian first lady Olena Zelenska preordered a $4 million luxury sports car while visiting France originated on a French website that was created June 22. | A Bugatti Automobiles S.A.S. spokesperson said Zelenska did not buy one of its vehicles. | Ukraine’s Center for Countering Disinformation called the claim Russian propaganda. | Verite Cachee, where the claim first appeared, contains other articles that left instructions on how to write with a pro-Russia slant.
label: refutes

claim: “Planes full of unvetted ‘refugees’ are being accepted at the Milw. & Madison airports!”
evidence: Migrants, asylum seekers or other kinds of immigrants have not been transported en masse to Wisconsin cities. | The federal government flies refugees to the U.S. for resettlement on commercial planes. They are highly vetted and arrive legally.
label: refutes

claim: Video shows Dr. Ben Carson promoting an erectile dysfunction treatment.
evidence: This video is "completely fake," said Brad Bishop, a spokesperson for Dr. Ben Carson.
label: refutes

claim: “WNBA organizers have officially announced an investigation into the referees in all of Caitlin Clark's games for ignoring all dirty actions by her opponents against her.”
evidence: There’s no evidence to support this claim.
label: refutes

claim: Michael J. Fox “doesn’t have Parkinson’s disease.”
evidence: This claim is unfounded. Actor and activist Michael J. Fox was diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease in 1991 and made that diagnosis public in 1998.
label: refutes

claim: “Just Stop Oil activists paint Taylor Swift’s private jets.”
evidence: Activists painted planes after singer Taylor Swift landed at the airport, but they didn’t paint Swift’s private jet.
label: refutes

claim: “R. Kelly has been released from United States of America Federal Prison, Chicago.”
evidence: R. Kelly is still incarcerated, serving a 30-year prison sentence.
label: refutes

claim: Border Patrol agents take migrants "to the Yuma airport, put them on a plane to any destination they want. ... And they pay their ticket. And then they get reimbursement from FEMA."
evidence: Migrants must pay for their own flights or transportation after they’ve been released from U.S. Border Patrol custody. | The Federal Emergency Management Agency reimburses some nonprofits that help migrants pay for their travel. But that is unrelated to Border Patrol.
label: refutes

claim: El 30 de junio de 2024 falleció el expresidente de Estados Unidos Barack Obama.
evidence: El expresidente de Estados Unidos Barack Obama no falleció el 30 de junio en un accidente de helicóptero. | PolitiFact no encontró reportes verídicos de medios que confirmen su muerte o de que haya tenido un accidente aéreo.
label: refutes

claim: A 2019 clip from the show “Project Runway,” with a face mask and a designer named Kovid, is proof that the COVID-19 pandemic was a hoax.
evidence: Kovid Kapoor, a contestant on "Project Runway," a fashion design competition television show, said in an interview that he used a face mask as part of his 2019 design in reference to air pollution. | Kapoor’s first name, Kovid, is a Hindi name meaning "scholar or learned person." | Claims that government leaders and those in power planned the COVID-19 pandemic have persisted since 2020; there is no credible evidence to back the claims.
label: refutes

claim: Photo shows a missing child in Pike County, Missouri.
evidence: The girl in this photo isn’t missing from Pike County, Missouri. She was briefly missing from a North Carolina community but has since been located.
label: refutes

claim: The city of San Francisco posted street signs warning that “stolen goods must remain under $950.”
evidence: City officials did not post street signs in San Francisco that appeared to warn thieves that "stolen goods must remain under $950," the city’s Board of Supervisors president said. The city has removed the signs. | Proposition 47, a California ballot measure voters passed in 2014, lowered some nonviolent felony crimes to misdemeanors, including shoplifting, as long as items taken totaled less than $950. People convicted of that crime face six months in prison and/or fines of up to $1,000.
label: refutes

claim: “Gordon Ramsay kicks Lia Thomas out of his restaurant, 'Dine in some woke place.'"
evidence: This claim originated as satire.
label: refutes

claim: “The weapons that Ukraine used in the early days of this war to fend off the Russian invasion are the weapons that Donald Trump sent, that Barack Obama and Joe Biden had refused to send.”
evidence: The Obama administration in 2014 rejected Ukraine’s request for lethal aid. | The Trump administration in 2018 approved a plan to sell Javelin missiles to Ukraine. | The Biden administration has approved billions of dollars in assistance to Ukraine, including Javelins.
label: supports

claim: A jury “ordered Disney and Lucasfilm to pay” actor Gina Carano $115 million.
evidence: This claim originated on a self-described satire website. | "The Mandalorian" actor Gina Carano has sued Disney for wrongful termination, but the lawsuit continues.
label: refutes

claim: Says as of June 30, “the decision has been made that (President Joe Biden) will quit the campaign.”
evidence: As of July 1, neither President Joe Biden nor his campaign had announced that Biden will exit the presidential race. | We found no credible news reports corroborating former Fox News host Bill O’Reilly’s claim. | A Biden campaign spokesperson told PolitiFact on July 1 that O’Reilly’s post was not accurate.
label: refutes

claim: “Nuevo programa en línea está enviando a estudiantes laptops Apple gratis y subvenciones en efectivo".
evidence: PolitiFact no encontró un supuesto programa para estudiantes que regale computadoras portátiles de la marca Apple y dinero en efectivo.
label: refutes

claim: Chiefs' Coach Andy Reid "fires 3 top players for anthem kneeling."
evidence: This story originated on a self-described satire website.
label: refutes

claim: "No live audience” at CNN debate means “We are watching a scripted movie.”
evidence: President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump agreed not to have a live studio audience during their June 27 debate in Atlanta. | Both candidates spoke about their debate performances in campaign rallies the day after.
label: refutes

claim: "There were 42,000 people diagnosed with (an) STD in Houston” in one week.
evidence: A social media post that claimed Houston had reported 42,000 sexually transmitted disease cases in one week shared a chart that city and state health officials said reflect the number of statewide tests, not confirmed Houston cases. | A Houston Health Department spokesperson said the numbers in the post were "grossly overstated" and "incorrect," and the result of a "misuse" of a data system.
label: refutes

claim: “Actor and comedian Tim Allen died suddenly” in a “fatal car accident.”
evidence: There is no credible reporting of Tim Allen’s death. | He has an event scheduled for June 29 that had not been canceled as of this publication.
label: refutes

claim: The Gates Foundation “awarded $9.5 million to UW-Madison to make H5N1 bird flu transmissible to humans.”
evidence: In 2009, the Gates Foundation awarded a five-year $9.5 million research grant to the University of Wisconsin-Madison. The university said the grant was set to fund efforts to identify virus mutations that could help identify influenza threats to humans. | Bill Gates and the Gates Foundation have been the target of false online claims for years, and this claim was first shared by websites and social media accounts that have spread misinformation.
label: refutes
